A yellow dressinggown, ungirdled, was sustained gently behind him on the mild morning air.	9.354375132843046
He held the bowl aloft and intoned: —_Introibo ad altare Dei_.	10.022628739736925
Halted, he peered down the dark winding stairs and called out coarsely: —Come up, Kinch! Come up, you fearful jesuit! Solemnly he came forward and mounted the round gunrest.	18.782879540778094
He faced about and blessed gravely thrice the tower, the surrounding land and the awaking mountains.	10.787913291431142
Then, catching sight of Stephen Dedalus, he bent towards him and made rapid crosses in the air, gurgling in his throat and shaking his head.	13.590056125582102
Stephen Dedalus, displeased and sleepy, leaned his arms on the top of the staircase and looked coldly at the shaking gurgling face that blessed him, equine in its length, and at the light untonsured hair, grained and hued like pale oak.	13.082317352793753
Buck Mulligan peeped an instant under the mirror and then covered the bowl smartly.	23.22063162078846
—Back to barracks! he said sternly.	14.35885316824227
He added in a preacher’s tone: —For this, O dearly beloved, is the genuine Christine: body and soul and blood and ouns.	13.791514571896577
Shut your eyes, gents.	19.435978688152108
One moment.	7.851822056789469
A little trouble about those white corpuscles.	11.469341083222146
Silence, all.	9.843607963174879
He peered sideways up and gave a long slow whistle of call, then paused awhile in rapt attention, his even white teeth glistening here and there with gold points.	11.634039141503058
Chrysostomos.	32.13581597679176
Two strong shrill whistles answered through the calm.	10.547030281649674
—Thanks, old chap, he cried briskly.	14.02091019504305
That will do nicely.	12.219458962182898
Switch off the current, will you?	8.218050038706359
He skipped off the gunrest and looked gravely at his watcher, gathering about his legs the loose folds of his gown.	12.911650966952838
The plump shadowed face and sullen oval jowl recalled a prelate, patron of arts in the middle ages.	6.189438981783939
A pleasant smile broke quietly over his lips.	5.6905613972382465
—The mockery of it! he said gaily.	17.17774688003216
Your absurd name, an ancient Greek! He pointed his finger in friendly jest and went over to the parapet, laughing to himself.	12.383016429928784
Stephen Dedalus stepped up, followed him wearily halfway and sat down on the edge of the gunrest, watching him still as he propped his mirror on the parapet, dipped the brush in the bowl and lathered cheeks and neck.	12.228762985179966
—My name is absurd too: Malachi Mulligan, two dactyls.	18.39590643869821
But it has a Hellenic ring, hasn’t it?	9.414089832988278
Tripping and sunny like the buck himself.	8.705251011363263
We must go to Athens.	27.47153934125334
Will you come if I can get the aunt to fork out twenty quid?	8.810747826251934
He laid the brush aside and, laughing with delight, cried: —Will he come?	22.60169703306097
The jejune jesuit! Ceasing, he began to shave with care.	9.501449895180217
—Tell me, Mulligan, Stephen said quietly.	19.72937812271938
—Yes, my love?	32.316312579622135
—How long is Haines going to stay in this tower?	19.78311017235144
Buck Mulligan showed a shaven cheek over his right shoulder.	12.653106487938542
—God, isn’t he dreadful?	18.799542510152595
he said frankly.	44.03155432905063
He thinks you’re not a gentleman.	9.441223396679236
God, these bloody English! Bursting with money and indigestion.	9.664358743914773
Because he comes from Oxford.	24.60946982425277
You know, Dedalus, you have the real Oxford manner.	25.42499626291462
He can’t make you out.	13.233832267114119
O, my name for you is the best: Kinch, the knife-blade.	30.514000900351284
He shaved warily over his chin.	11.33065710502632
—He was raving all night about a black panther, Stephen said.	10.028104088782417
Where is his guncase?	34.80086704566863
—A woful lunatic! Mulligan said.	5.32016673304738
Were you in a funk?	36.76565972940926
—I was, Stephen said with energy and growing fear.	12.638949306218343
Out here in the dark with a man I don’t know raving and moaning to himself about shooting a black panther.	12.03959130503638
I’m not a hero, however.	13.827107278954717
Buck Mulligan frowned at the lather on his razorblade.	31.878786789749814
He hopped down from his perch and began to search his trouser pockets hastily.	8.124212718874963
—Scutter! he cried thickly.	11.175790050898943
He came over to the gunrest and, thrusting a hand into Stephen’s upper pocket, said: —Lend us a loan of your noserag to wipe my razor.	13.328821106868599
Stephen suffered him to pull out and hold up on show by its corner a dirty crumpled handkerchief.	13.819386817070322
Buck Mulligan wiped the razorblade neatly.	12.089737026413149
Then, gazing over the handkerchief, he said: —The bard’s noserag! A new art colour for our Irish poets: snotgreen.	13.712143131741982
You can almost taste it, can’t you?	14.01875640540074
He mounted to the parapet again and gazed out over Dublin bay, his fair oakpale hair stirring slightly.	13.434536713813277
—God! he said quietly.	13.947659567333519
Isn’t the sea what Algy calls it: a great sweet mother?	20.596956274837616
The snotgreen sea.	5.95504205364476
The scrotumtightening sea.	5.95504205364476
_Epi oinopa ponton_.	14.786396833216765
Ah, Dedalus, the Greeks! I must teach you.	33.40181911781661
You must read them in the original.	19.31999439027103
_Thalatta! Thalatta!_ She is our great sweet mother.	10.162224931045655
Come and look.	17.225574683195212
Stephen stood up and went over to the parapet.	13.166593877102466
Leaning on it he looked down on the water and on the mailboat clearing the harbourmouth of Kingstown.	15.969156318926531
—Our mighty mother! Buck Mulligan said.	5.065243053973324
He turned abruptly his grey searching eyes from the sea to Stephen’s face.	11.076552935767339
—The aunt thinks you killed your mother, he said.	6.501073655185598
That’s why she won’t let me have anything to do with you.	9.204447547201806
—Someone killed her, Stephen said gloomily.	25.009876097976413
—You could have knelt down, damn it, Kinch, when your dying mother asked you, Buck Mulligan said.	14.872450755120612
I’m hyperborean as much as you.	10.908990105510805
But to think of your mother begging you with her last breath to kneel down and pray for her.	10.874559123223877
And you refused.	19.289122266343515
There is something sinister in you....	5.548366444470281
He broke off and lathered again lightly his farther cheek.	7.0866617364823075
A tolerant smile curled his lips.	4.157229693800875
—But a lovely mummer! he murmured to himself.	15.60736527463652
Kinch, the loveliest mummer of them all! He shaved evenly and with care, in silence, seriously.	21.39949503876984
Stephen, an elbow rested on the jagged granite, leaned his palm against his brow and gazed at the fraying edge of his shiny black coat-sleeve.	13.569815555688367
Pain, that was not yet the pain of love, fretted his heart.	11.371943699965973
Silently, in a dream she had come to him after her death, her wasted body within its loose brown graveclothes giving off an odour of wax and rosewood, her breath, that had bent upon him, mute, reproachful, a faint odour of wetted ashes.	6.779953215362319
Across the threadbare cuffedge he saw the sea hailed as a great sweet mother by the wellfed voice beside him.	9.364345398150451
The ring of bay and skyline held a dull green mass of liquid.	9.195609331709957
Buck Mulligan wiped again his razorblade.	14.556984653799997
—Ah, poor dogsbody! he said in a kind voice.	14.107328337464113
I must give you a shirt and a few noserags.	32.86612197738191
How are the secondhand breeks?	18.359662156380068
—They fit well enough, Stephen answered.	11.41329644203811
Buck Mulligan attacked the hollow beneath his underlip.	16.98692510742101
—The mockery of it, he said contentedly.	16.858693394855624
Secondleg they should be.	10.554404256643833
God knows what poxy bowsy left them off.	6.6826152556093135
I have a lovely pair with a hair stripe, grey.	18.121795507406397
You’ll look spiffing in them.	9.489227019396525
I’m not joking, Kinch.	9.61027567692413
You look damn well when you’re dressed.	15.039462314226968
—Thanks, Stephen said.	4.6168437346026865
I can’t wear them if they are grey.	12.638027273425438
—He can’t wear them, Buck Mulligan told his face in the mirror.	17.65665002210777
He kills his mother but he can’t wear grey trousers.	12.032621374935601
He folded his razor neatly and with stroking palps of fingers felt the smooth skin.	6.762279856710714
Stephen turned his gaze from the sea and to the plump face with its smokeblue mobile eyes.	14.887697516928966
—That fellow I was with in the Ship last night, said Buck Mulligan, says you have g.	33.6588945375876
p.	17.685021073205338
i.	32.13581597679176
He’s up in Dottyville with Connolly Norman.	12.822625352767608
General paralysis of the insane! He swept the mirror a half circle in the air to flash the tidings abroad in sunlight now radiant on the sea.	10.15289447365196
His curling shaven lips laughed and the edges of his white glittering teeth.	12.013218734079302
Laughter seized all his strong wellknit trunk.	8.221725932573145
—Look at yourself, he said, you dreadful bard! Stephen bent forward and peered at the mirror held out to him, cleft by a crooked crack.	9.504466830343377
Hair on end.	9.984191100479144
As he and others see me.	11.90208292349287
Who chose this face for me?	6.538745630257135
This dogsbody to rid of vermin.	7.907914236519451
It asks me too.	8.514509755641445
—I pinched it out of the skivvy’s room, Buck Mulligan said.	12.654492063324177
It does her all right.	7.3059334230160085
The aunt always keeps plainlooking servants for Malachi.	5.625512374648339
Lead him not into temptation.	11.296873571782095
And her name is Ursula.	24.95748249297839
Laughing again, he brought the mirror away from Stephen’s peering eyes.	17.56413270144845
—The rage of Caliban at not seeing his face in a mirror, he said.	8.860290119994431
If Wilde were only alive to see you! Drawing back and pointing, Stephen said with bitterness: —It is a symbol of Irish art.	11.690734915191573
The cracked lookingglass of a servant.	8.591850270003613
Buck Mulligan suddenly linked his arm in Stephen’s and walked with him round the tower, his razor and mirror clacking in the pocket where he had thrust them.	16.409889440048445
—It’s not fair to tease you like that, Kinch, is it?	12.102610768299222
he said kindly.	23.37726199077358
God knows you have more spirit than any of them.	11.400952130520393
Parried again.	5.909382163877581
He fears the lancet of my art as I fear that of his.	12.240734844870731
The cold steel pen.	16.33567991480922
—Cracked lookingglass of a servant! Tell that to the oxy chap downstairs and touch him for a guinea.	13.30631707270977
He’s stinking with money and thinks you’re not a gentleman.	10.940332062422472
His old fellow made his tin by selling jalap to Zulus or some bloody swindle or other.	7.164463397519208
God, Kinch, if you and I could only work together we might do something for the island.	26.9403266223391
Hellenise it.	4.258023366747632
Cranly’s arm.	12.976952782873061
His arm.	12.429226669332564
—And to think of your having to beg from these swine.	13.248544276722889
I’m the only one that knows what you are.	20.17801387103311
Why don’t you trust me more?	12.399090174487785
What have you up your nose against me?	13.053251206359814
Is it Haines?	24.468378765106014
If he makes any noise here I’ll bring down Seymour and we’ll give him a ragging worse than they gave Clive Kempthorpe.	9.500348514498635
Young shouts of moneyed voices in Clive Kempthorpe’s rooms.	9.737067091110932
Palefaces: they hold their ribs with laughter, one clasping another.	8.549006059421568
O, I shall expire! Break the news to her gently, Aubrey! I shall die! With slit ribbons of his shirt whipping the air he hops and hobbles round the table, with trousers down at heels, chased by Ades of Magdalen with the tailor’s shears.	13.338142503018334
A scared calf’s face gilded with marmalade.	8.754525311613664
I don’t want to be debagged! Don’t you play the giddy ox with me! Shouts from the open window startling evening in the quadrangle.	11.913540490743577
A deaf gardener, aproned, masked with Matthew Arnold’s face, pushes his mower on the sombre lawn watching narrowly the dancing motes of grasshalms.	5.654356450416481
new paganism...	2.739065420347036
omphalos.	32.13581597679176
—Let him stay, Stephen said.	4.542925649210035
There’s nothing wrong with him except at night.	14.384071043254204
—Then what is it?	6.495948332185265
Buck Mulligan asked impatiently.	17.11666084987899
Cough it up.	4.908116716512725
I’m quite frank with you.	6.95433043987144
What have you against me now?	14.514278477684604
They halted, looking towards the blunt cape of Bray Head that lay on the water like the snout of a sleeping whale.	13.978338590674754
Stephen freed his arm quietly.	9.822168588694156
—Do you wish me to tell you?	18.385830119428082
—Yes, what is it?	8.453482298565943
Buck Mulligan answered.	10.0472061286583
I don’t remember anything.	7.639582425386718
He looked in Stephen’s face as he spoke.	18.08909915076861
A light wind passed his brow, fanning softly his fair uncombed hair and stirring silver points of anxiety in his eyes.	5.577036996745628
Stephen, depressed by his own voice, said: —Do you remember the first day I went to your house after my mother’s death?	24.805745673433435
Buck Mulligan frowned quickly and said: —What?	12.26840890000176
Where?	14.036610527842967
I can’t remember anything.	7.386013880321848
I remember only ideas and sensations.	12.107345568102351
Why?	12.497976142926124
What happened in the name of God?	17.262696725572727
—You were making tea, Stephen said, and went across the landing to get more hot water.	19.947040161771923
Your mother and some visitor came out of the drawingroom.	16.422404185726638
She asked you who was in your room.	32.39359423216341
—Yes?	25.13740288548873
What did I say?	21.010112394006637
I forget.	24.81632615462123
—You said, Stephen answered, _O, it’s only Dedalus whose mother is beastly dead._ A flush which made him seem younger and more engaging rose to Buck Mulligan’s cheek.	10.626421310968619
—Did I say that?	19.182062873619607
Well?	17.685021073205338
What harm is that?	7.545287656455477
He shook his constraint from him nervously.	9.883933432323873
—And what is death, he asked, your mother’s or yours or my own?	24.969809999812558
You saw only your mother die.	8.714440556726801
I see them pop off every day in the Mater and Richmond and cut up into tripes in the dissectingroom.	13.42942455836813
It’s a beastly thing and nothing else.	13.778890666945097
It simply doesn’t matter.	11.081541126080852
You wouldn’t kneel down to pray for your mother on her deathbed when she asked you.	14.608642748071764
Why?	12.497976142926124
Because you have the cursed jesuit strain in you, only it’s injected the wrong way.	14.903635259591729
To me it’s all a mockery and beastly.	12.362924048149777
She calls the doctor sir Peter Teazle and picks buttercups off the quilt.	9.908297869167724
Humour her till it’s over.	11.324919287814392
You crossed her last wish in death and yet you sulk with me because I don’t whinge like some hired mute from Lalouette’s.	7.983581956689778
Absurd! I suppose I did say it.	14.381724804258244
I didn’t mean to offend the memory of your mother.	8.036282064005597
He had spoken himself into boldness.	13.052642310164256
Stephen, shielding the gaping wounds which the words had left in his heart, said very coldly: —I am not thinking of the offence to my mother.	21.07980473584426
—Of what then?	14.572036941433073
Buck Mulligan asked.	9.819963444641035
—Of the offence to me, Stephen answered.	10.626851592513619
Buck Mulligan swung round on his heel.	27.215197741019843
—O, an impossible person! he exclaimed.	20.915627404856128
Stephen stood at his post, gazing over the calm sea towards the headland.	18.231514277167737
Sea and headland now grew dim.	6.14633179370776
Pulses were beating in his eyes, veiling their sight, and he felt the fever of his cheeks.	14.149961677678203
A voice within the tower called loudly: —Are you up there, Mulligan?	22.327838039102815
—I’m coming, Buck Mulligan answered.	9.488150822809821
He turned towards Stephen and said: —Look at the sea.	14.501818968422597
What does it care about offences?	18.752069898155586
Chuck Loyola, Kinch, and come on down.	17.621580718494677
The Sassenach wants his morning rashers.	6.14633179370776
His head halted again for a moment at the top of the staircase, level with the roof: —Don’t mope over it all day, he said.	14.309157341189461
I’m inconsequent.	24.08682475129976
Give up the moody brooding.	15.609339338240865
His head vanished but the drone of his descending voice boomed out of the stairhead: And no more turn aside and brood Upon love’s bitter mystery For Fergus rules the brazen cars.	10.298100325135083
Woodshadows floated silently by through the morning peace from the stairhead seaward where he gazed.	14.947946947565217
Inshore and farther out the mirror of water whitened, spurned by lightshod hurrying feet.	7.716472369757602
White breast of the dim sea.	15.000873277418235
The twining stresses, two by two.	5.94990065493008
A hand plucking the harpstrings, merging their twining chords.	4.525227685280991
A cloud began to cover the sun slowly, wholly, shadowing the bay in deeper green.	6.262276127949248
It lay beneath him, a bowl of bitter waters.	14.49953742673495
Fergus’ song: I sang it alone in the house, holding down the long dark chords.	15.186591764712333
Her door was open: she wanted to hear my music.	13.250739660833634
Silent with awe and pity I went to her bedside.	14.57784263120018
She was crying in her wretched bed.	14.512834717184596
For those words, Stephen: love’s bitter mystery.	19.522941929827624
Where now?	7.942397141020434
Her secrets: old featherfans, tasselled dancecards, powdered with musk, a gaud of amber beads in her locked drawer.	5.54609648382192
A birdcage hung in the sunny window of her house when she was a girl.	17.039975112592582
She heard old Royce sing in the pantomime of Turko the Terrible and laughed with others when he sang: I am the boy That can enjoy Invisibility.	9.594487129663719
Phantasmal mirth, folded away: muskperfumed.	8.120448727366957
Folded away in the memory of nature with her toys.	20.301577813136927
Memories beset his brooding brain.	5.483102864076354
Her glass of water from the kitchen tap when she had approached the sacrament.	20.547685170543783
A cored apple, filled with brown sugar, roasting for her at the hob on a dark autumn evening.	11.929452633042258
Her shapely fingernails reddened by the blood of squashed lice from the children’s shirts.	16.513663006204084
In a dream, silently, she had come to him, her wasted body within its loose graveclothes giving off an odour of wax and rosewood, her breath, bent over him with mute secret words, a faint odour of wetted ashes.	3.9143675583373017
Her glazing eyes, staring out of death, to shake and bend my soul.	14.552727482829667
On me alone.	10.133274831778289
The ghostcandle to light her agony.	7.316524124689606
Ghostly light on the tortured face.	10.11727554714152
Her hoarse loud breath rattling in horror, while all prayed on their knees.	6.965705920070913
Her eyes on me to strike me down.	26.49896152136875
_Liliata rutilantium te confessorum turma circumdet: iubilantium te virginum chorus excipiat._ Ghoul! Chewer of corpses! No, mother! Let me be and let me live.	6.758422364666659
—Kinch ahoy! Buck Mulligan’s voice sang from within the tower.	9.8493527826859
It came nearer up the staircase, calling again.	8.603831722029526

Haines is apologising for waking us last night.	4.29836632193855
It’s all right.	5.592046872441169

How much?	15.28412872216335
Four quid?	12.599684944605478
Lend us one.	10.484022561268715

We’ll have a glorious drunk to astonish the druidy druids.	9.312260961815129
Four omnipotent sovereigns.	8.949652011548354
He flung up his hands and tramped down the stone stairs, singing out of tune with a Cockney accent: O, won’t we have a merry time, Drinking whisky, beer and wine! On coronation, Coronation day! O, won’t we have a merry time On coronation day! Warm sunshine merrying over the sea.	9.10418849663748
The nickel shavingbowl shone, forgotten, on the parapet.	8.072239149356275
Why should I bring it down?	17.17786919522031
Or leave it there all day, forgotten friendship?	16.18901973182987
He went over to it, held it in his hands awhile, feeling its coolness, smelling the clammy slaver of the lather in which the brush was stuck.	18.229135676125665
So I carried the boat of incense then at Clongowes.	12.658058026598109
I am another now and yet the same.	19.443552259736204
A servant too.	4.387016086573923
A server of a servant.	14.935047453159562
In the gloomy domed livingroom of the tower Buck Mulligan’s gowned form moved briskly to and fro about the hearth, hiding and revealing its yellow glow.	10.76933431198535
Two shafts of soft daylight fell across the flagged floor from the high barbacans: and at the meeting of their rays a cloud of coalsmoke and fumes of fried grease floated, turning.	10.503596993980079
—We’ll be choked, Buck Mulligan said.	4.654604494923057
Haines, open that door, will you?	7.026625873574793
Stephen laid the shavingbowl on the locker.	14.129458556286693
A tall figure rose from the hammock where it had been sitting, went to the doorway and pulled open the inner doors.	17.28824660026884
—Have you the key?	14.315088497461176
a voice asked.	8.139974284576594
—Dedalus has it, Buck Mulligan said.	6.281636843745513
Janey Mack, I’m choked! He howled, without looking up from the fire: —Kinch! —It’s in the lock, Stephen said, coming forward.	15.49807629436211
The key scraped round harshly twice and, when the heavy door had been set ajar, welcome light and bright air entered.	9.740828886849936
Haines stood at the doorway, looking out.	12.616318670544915
Stephen haled his upended valise to the table and sat down to wait.	7.367885066864577
Buck Mulligan tossed the fry on to the dish beside him.	12.173715185755746
Then he carried the dish and a large teapot over to the table, set them down heavily and sighed with relief.	11.766471267406331
—I’m melting, he said, as the candle remarked when...	8.096511095005107
But, hush! Not a word more on that subject! Kinch, wake up! Bread, butter, honey.	11.140850543058987
The grub is ready.	6.186442684388578
Bless us, O Lord, and these thy gifts.	25.86437357065693
Where’s the sugar?	25.100228703273505
O, jay, there’s no milk.	14.686504634137185
Stephen fetched the loaf and the pot of honey and the buttercooler from the locker.	20.777317058117106
Buck Mulligan sat down in a sudden pet.	22.70554974835358
he said.	3.724527490343976
I told her to come after eight.	18.039173582446878
—We can drink it black, Stephen said thirstily.	16.412275414740723
There’s a lemon in the locker.	24.83147782487281
—O, damn you and your Paris fads! Buck Mulligan said.	6.390186908667816
I want Sandycove milk.	14.578692014088714
Haines came in from the doorway and said quietly: —That woman is coming up with the milk.	27.982423752816924
—The blessings of God on you! Buck Mulligan cried, jumping up from his chair.	21.69947243140683
Sit down.	7.866648935156897
Pour out the tea there.	9.14920935319541
The sugar is in the bag.	20.219611718428762
Here, I can’t go fumbling at the damned eggs.	16.852918857702065
He hacked through the fry on the dish and slapped it out on three plates, saying: —_In nomine Patris et Filii et Spiritus Sancti._ Haines sat down to pour out the tea.	9.13085818398404
—I’m giving you two lumps each, he said.	7.524108308242199
But, I say, Mulligan, you do make strong tea, don’t you?	16.268939105441095
Buck Mulligan, hewing thick slices from the loaf, said in an old woman’s wheedling voice: —When I makes tea I makes tea, as old mother Grogan said.	18.377881952817546
And when I makes water I makes water.	11.507822676878542
—By Jove, it is tea, Haines said.	9.068000425253127
Buck Mulligan went on hewing and wheedling: —_So I do, Mrs Cahill,_ says she.	15.891338019832158
_Begob, ma’am,_ says Mrs Cahill, _God send you don’t make them in the one pot._ He lunged towards his messmates in turn a thick slice of bread, impaled on his knife.	10.055801907418527
—That’s folk, he said very earnestly, for your book, Haines.	21.545597897024003
Five lines of text and ten pages of notes about the folk and the fishgods of Dundrum.	10.917773805997633
Printed by the weird sisters in the year of the big wind.	20.19368116467767
He turned to Stephen and asked in a fine puzzled voice, lifting his brows: —Can you recall, brother, is mother Grogan’s tea and water pot spoken of in the Mabinogion or is it in the Upanishads?	19.85492003756001
—I doubt it, said Stephen gravely.	32.24233864819559
Buck Mulligan said in the same tone.	27.882737722812315
Your reasons, pray?	17.009546616257122
—I fancy, Stephen said as he ate, it did not exist in or out of the Mabinogion.	23.751100728331995
Mother Grogan was, one imagines, a kinswoman of Mary Ann.	21.04173837996317
Buck Mulligan’s face smiled with delight.	12.53009790561072
—Charming! he said in a finical sweet voice, showing his white teeth and blinking his eyes pleasantly.	13.791702903028
Do you think she was?	30.67625827749565
Quite charming! Then, suddenly overclouding all his features, he growled in a hoarsened rasping voice as he hewed again vigorously at the loaf: _—For old Mary Ann She doesn’t care a damn.	14.3188374381236
But, hising up her petticoats..._ He crammed his mouth with fry and munched and droned.	11.962363545942717
The doorway was darkened by an entering form.	5.968415348102963
Kinch, get the jug.	45.98471033016545
An old woman came forward and stood by Stephen’s elbow.	26.910629413416622
—That’s a lovely morning, sir, she said.	2.4580414401392043
Glory be to God.	6.95716652941755
—To whom?	25.49262508376742
Mulligan said, glancing at her.	12.104391407339838
Ah, to be sure! Stephen reached back and took the milkjug from the locker.	21.818775919604082
—The islanders, Mulligan said to Haines casually, speak frequently of the collector of prepuces.	13.77141750733724
—How much, sir?	21.62277956022868
asked the old woman.	16.927730991218983
—A quart, Stephen said.	7.6090971507171705
He watched her pour into the measure and thence into the jug rich white milk, not hers.	13.631644090012559
Old shrunken paps.	11.148858409578036
She poured again a measureful and a tilly.	14.547502612465514
Old and secret she had entered from a morning world, maybe a messenger.	12.530567139349001
She praised the goodness of the milk, pouring it out.	14.76610567654824
Crouching by a patient cow at daybreak in the lush field, a witch on her toadstool, her wrinkled fingers quick at the squirting dugs.	14.881791909288891
They lowed about her whom they knew, dewsilky cattle.	9.04256796631786
Silk of the kine and poor old woman, names given her in old times.	11.657901207477352
A wandering crone, lowly form of an immortal serving her conqueror and her gay betrayer, their common cuckquean, a messenger from the secret morning.	10.765842762921256
To serve or to upbraid, whether he could not tell: but scorned to beg her favour.	10.423565567744326
—It is indeed, ma’am, Buck Mulligan said, pouring milk into their cups.	11.375534200164525
—Taste it, sir, she said.	1.1955876062430482
He drank at her bidding.	20.89216979122409
—If we could live on good food like that, he said to her somewhat loudly, we wouldn’t have the country full of rotten teeth and rotten guts.	13.338856558504123
Living in a bogswamp, eating cheap food and the streets paved with dust, horsedung and consumptives’ spits.	8.433983590720686
—Are you a medical student, sir?	11.050359347397698
the old woman asked.	12.976253751950857
—I am, ma’am, Buck Mulligan answered.	8.165033027522497
—Look at that now, she said.	2.3204312821065267
Stephen listened in scornful silence.	6.236313947861035
She bows her old head to a voice that speaks to her loudly, her bonesetter, her medicineman: me she slights.	14.385623275019189
To the voice that will shrive and oil for the grave all there is of her but her woman’s unclean loins, of man’s flesh made not in God’s likeness, the serpent’s prey.	24.689046312129776
And to the loud voice that now bids her be silent with wondering unsteady eyes.	11.3725793920362
—Do you understand what he says?	30.953079821790876
Stephen asked her.	8.237517173289245
—Is it French you are talking, sir?	10.716691473912167
the old woman said to Haines.	14.220083223517916
Haines spoke to her again a longer speech, confidently.	13.336119392268909
—Irish, Buck Mulligan said.	5.551533926962829
Is there Gaelic on you?	6.808385524364878
—I thought it was Irish, she said, by the sound of it.	6.815456287164303
Are you from the west, sir?	35.508814188767566
—I am an Englishman, Haines answered.	15.840159262809161
—He’s English, Buck Mulligan said, and he thinks we ought to speak Irish in Ireland.	13.52398597094322
—Sure we ought to, the old woman said, and I’m ashamed I don’t speak the language myself.	14.20147958006792
I’m told it’s a grand language by them that knows.	17.0620064264342
—Grand is no name for it, said Buck Mulligan.	21.55411830190582
Wonderful entirely.	16.58211792698403
Fill us out some more tea, Kinch.	10.741633185267208
Would you like a cup, ma’am?	14.41002149643933
—No, thank you, sir, the old woman said, slipping the ring of the milkcan on her forearm and about to go.	13.081877971824898
Haines said to her: —Have you your bill?	32.22813783422469
We had better pay her, Mulligan, hadn’t we?	13.149090328590718
Stephen filled again the three cups.	16.06567989492702
—Bill, sir?	7.009560141623047
she said, halting.	35.51207824275101
Well, it’s seven mornings a pint at twopence is seven twos is a shilling and twopence over and these three mornings a quart at fourpence is three quarts is a shilling.	8.64170527073733
That’s a shilling and one and two is two and two, sir.	13.434760533292144
Buck Mulligan sighed and, having filled his mouth with a crust thickly buttered on both sides, stretched forth his legs and began to search his trouser pockets.	11.662447664856746
—Pay up and look pleasant, Haines said to him, smiling.	3.3463217372371243
Stephen filled a third cup, a spoonful of tea colouring faintly the thick rich milk.	11.757950632141478
Buck Mulligan brought up a florin, twisted it round in his fingers and cried: —A miracle! He passed it along the table towards the old woman, saying: —Ask nothing more of me, sweet.	19.712531143363464
All I can give you I give.	21.5674300556076
Stephen laid the coin in her uneager hand.	10.465910699369804
—We’ll owe twopence, he said.	5.296432433293203
—Time enough, sir, she said, taking the coin.	3.821514344242881
Time enough.	11.943845981129963
Good morning, sir.	3.744215129923402
She curtseyed and went out, followed by Buck Mulligan’s tender chant: _—Heart of my heart, were it more, More would be laid at your feet._ He turned to Stephen and said: —Seriously, Dedalus.	16.04397892256956
I’m stony.	24.08682475129976
Hurry out to your school kip and bring us back some money.	8.791023329643258
Today the bards must drink and junket.	7.733956077402238
Ireland expects that every man this day will do his duty.	9.900770819217858
—That reminds me, Haines said, rising, that I have to visit your national library today.	16.79621973454419
—Our swim first, Buck Mulligan said.	5.699664266699097
He turned to Stephen and asked blandly: —Is this the day for your monthly wash, Kinch?	16.41927687170692
Then he said to Haines: —The unclean bard makes a point of washing once a month.	13.792669124141792
—All Ireland is washed by the gulfstream, Stephen said as he let honey trickle over a slice of the loaf.	15.086101907666846
Speaking to me.	4.985604041519075
They wash and tub and scrub.	8.38613991257032
Agenbite of inwit.	7.496728605607897
Conscience.	32.13581597679176
Yet here’s a spot.	12.90635566718131
—That one about the cracked lookingglass of a servant being the symbol of Irish art is deuced good.	11.81312043412257
Buck Mulligan kicked Stephen’s foot under the table and said with warmth of tone: —Wait till you hear him on Hamlet, Haines.	17.14993898182966
—Well, I mean it, Haines said, still speaking to Stephen.	16.34676028978656
I was just thinking of it when that poor old creature came in.	17.25530868555804
—Would I make any money by it?	7.285746307621941
Haines laughed and, as he took his soft grey hat from the holdfast of the hammock, said: —I don’t know, I’m sure.	14.071327850083785
He strolled out to the doorway.	16.13081497313115
Buck Mulligan bent across to Stephen and said with coarse vigour: —You put your hoof in it now.	9.901529991556098
What did you say that for?	21.86537193485889
—Well?	31.579380399266167
Stephen said.	4.142530577726673
The problem is to get money.	15.115601970832135
From whom?	11.725328032605423
From the milkwoman or from him.	7.698833548753367
—I blow him out about you, Buck Mulligan said, and then you come along with your lousy leer and your gloomy jesuit jibes.	14.386812109515647
—I see little hope, Stephen said, from her or from him.	16.099689760094442
Buck Mulligan sighed tragically and laid his hand on Stephen’s arm.	11.943837921484773
—From me, Kinch, he said.	9.397594070492655
In a suddenly changed tone he added: —To tell you the God’s truth I think you’re right.	13.534341955227504
Damn all else they are good for.	14.64620919346826
Why don’t you play them as I do?	15.506090236196098
To hell with them all.	7.913419839145834
Let us get out of the kip.	24.305418196330738
He stood up, gravely ungirdled and disrobed himself of his gown, saying resignedly: —Mulligan is stripped of his garments.	14.395747472157364
He emptied his pockets on to the table.	7.156676636947912
—There’s your snotrag, he said.	5.785311736738395
And putting on his stiff collar and rebellious tie he spoke to them, chiding them, and to his dangling watchchain.	16.88043203921023
His hands plunged and rummaged in his trunk while he called for a clean handkerchief.	15.499859518090618
God, we’ll simply have to dress the character.	12.69113700055613
I want puce gloves and green boots.	13.0252484844669
Contradiction.	32.13581597679176
Do I contradict myself?	9.910497547215114
Very well then, I contradict myself.	20.354867193349214
Mercurial Malachi.	16.688409521161915
A limp black missile flew out of his talking hands.	6.978577587354654
Stephen picked it up and put it on.	12.30154314415281
—I’m ready, Buck Mulligan answered, going towards the door.	13.992482418356786
Come out, Kinch.	22.495012129727524
You have eaten all we left, I suppose.	9.951299395077912
Resigned he passed out with grave words and gait, saying, wellnigh with sorrow: —And going forth he met Butterly.	9.469585942758668
Stephen, taking his ashplant from its leaningplace, followed them out and, as they went down the ladder, pulled to the slow iron door and locked it.	15.019212341946028
He put the huge key in his inner pocket.	17.155684753133126
At the foot of the ladder Buck Mulligan asked: —Did you bring the key?	20.55844121540195
—I have it, Stephen said, preceding them.	11.101377243830566
He walked on.	6.2943887622623915
Behind him he heard Buck Mulligan club with his heavy bathtowel the leader shoots of ferns or grasses.	13.291811450460553
—Down, sir! How dare you, sir! Haines asked: —Do you pay rent for this tower?	14.88059556150248
—Twelve quid, Buck Mulligan said.	3.3349693304117567
—To the secretary of state for war, Stephen added over his shoulder.	9.923119691105972
They halted while Haines surveyed the tower and said at last: —Rather bleak in wintertime, I should say.	11.9518170198242
Martello you call it?	6.145774566524289
—Billy Pitt had them built, Buck Mulligan said, when the French were on the sea.	7.553132476000978
But ours is the _omphalos_.	15.245211494169302
—What is your idea of Hamlet?	19.81188583063393
Haines asked Stephen.	8.65944294561986
—No, no, Buck Mulligan shouted in pain.	14.002511498037432
I’m not equal to Thomas Aquinas and the fiftyfive reasons he has made out to prop it up.	11.654145153020824
Wait till I have a few pints in me first.	16.139876844140833
He turned to Stephen, saying, as he pulled down neatly the peaks of his primrose waistcoat: —You couldn’t manage it under three pints, Kinch, could you?	12.744130254172015
—It has waited so long, Stephen said listlessly, it can wait longer.	15.412579190331524
—You pique my curiosity, Haines said amiably.	12.190876152196857
Is it some paradox?	20.782035072401037
—Pooh! Buck Mulligan said.	2.9271314425470503
We have grown out of Wilde and paradoxes.	19.80002943075132
It’s quite simple.	18.56969917201688
He proves by algebra that Hamlet’s grandson is Shakespeare’s grandfather and that he himself is the ghost of his own father.	12.39472052439244
Haines said, beginning to point at Stephen.	18.21054533462539
He himself?	15.782923272247585
Buck Mulligan slung his towel stolewise round his neck and, bending in loose laughter, said to Stephen’s ear: —O, shade of Kinch the elder! Japhet in search of a father! —We’re always tired in the morning, Stephen said to Haines.	13.261526057304243
And it is rather long to tell.	23.61172911405553
Buck Mulligan, walking forward again, raised his hands.	17.18969398472105
—The sacred pint alone can unbind the tongue of Dedalus, he said.	4.3972789853634335
—I mean to say, Haines explained to Stephen as they followed, this tower and these cliffs here remind me somehow of Elsinore.	18.00093655969934
_That beetles o’er his base into the sea,_ isn’t it?	7.895061325772189
Buck Mulligan turned suddenly for an instant towards Stephen but did not speak.	16.190767951308544
In the bright silent instant Stephen saw his own image in cheap dusty mourning between their gay attires.	10.671868359519989
—It’s a wonderful tale, Haines said, bringing them to halt again.	10.17868320928195
Eyes, pale as the sea the wind had freshened, paler, firm and prudent.	10.595922088686606
The seas’ ruler, he gazed southward over the bay, empty save for the smokeplume of the mailboat vague on the bright skyline and a sail tacking by the Muglins.	18.4804624702341
—I read a theological interpretation of it somewhere, he said bemused.	25.049360215790838
The Son striving to be atoned with the Father.	17.90062788158504
Buck Mulligan at once put on a blithe broadly smiling face.	15.26501012989841
He looked at them, his wellshaped mouth open happily, his eyes, from which he had suddenly withdrawn all shrewd sense, blinking with mad gaiety.	10.045851001568407
He moved a doll’s head to and fro, the brims of his Panama hat quivering, and began to chant in a quiet happy foolish voice: _—I’m the queerest young fellow that ever you heard.	15.43900743534774
My mother’s a jew, my father’s a bird.	16.80879923096914
With Joseph the joiner I cannot agree.	8.84284253478721
So here’s to disciples and Calvary._ He held up a forefinger of warning.	15.49525732331597
_—If anyone thinks that I amn’t divine He’ll get no free drinks when I’m making the wine But have to drink water and wish it were plain That I make when the wine becomes water again._ He tugged swiftly at Stephen’s ashplant in farewell and, running forward to a brow of the cliff, fluttered his hands at his sides like fins or wings of one about to rise in the air, and chanted: _—Goodbye, now, goodbye! Write down all I said And tell Tom, Dick and Harry I rose from the dead.	13.025736521406968
What’s bred in the bone cannot fail me to fly And Olivet’s breezy...	9.88492482397349
Goodbye, now, goodbye!_ He capered before them down towards the fortyfoot hole, fluttering his winglike hands, leaping nimbly, Mercury’s hat quivering in the fresh wind that bore back to them his brief birdsweet cries.	9.808300484923045
Haines, who had been laughing guardedly, walked on beside Stephen and said: —We oughtn’t to laugh, I suppose.	12.48814128994629
He’s rather blasphemous.	21.740343448100965
I’m not a believer myself, that is to say.	10.258777146037634
Still his gaiety takes the harm out of it somehow, doesn’t it?	5.618850945410725
What did he call it?	9.873592085626587
Joseph the Joiner?	16.92538249648606
—The ballad of joking Jesus, Stephen answered.	10.333350353090255
—O, Haines said, you have heard it before?	26.969553322714287
—Three times a day, after meals, Stephen said drily.	18.000996232642944
—You’re not a believer, are you?	7.959657725532631
Haines asked.	11.495592740981188
I mean, a believer in the narrow sense of the word.	28.617564336599646
Creation from nothing and miracles and a personal God.	8.107980674925669
—There’s only one sense of the word, it seems to me, Stephen said.	10.592286848215215
Haines stopped to take out a smooth silver case in which twinkled a green stone.	10.064495314140027
He sprang it open with his thumb and offered it.	7.122337438499186
—Thank you, Stephen said, taking a cigarette.	14.087796172308613
He put it back in his sidepocket and took from his waistcoatpocket a nickel tinderbox, sprang it open too, and, having lit his cigarette, held the flaming spunk towards Stephen in the shell of his hands.	15.885595839789843
—Yes, of course, he said, as they went on again.	11.726157632056486
Either you believe or you don’t, isn’t it?	6.292071928752239
Personally I couldn’t stomach that idea of a personal God.	11.628074489729803
You don’t stand for that, I suppose?	18.019933517116133
—You behold in me, Stephen said with grim displeasure, a horrible example of free thought.	12.305246674114931
He walked on, waiting to be spoken to, trailing his ashplant by his side.	23.20151666215354
Its ferrule followed lightly on the path, squealing at his heels.	13.18433936003461
My familiar, after me, calling, Steeeeeeeeeeeephen! A wavering line along the path.	14.815316004643776
They will walk on it tonight, coming here in the dark.	15.130993169273562
He wants that key.	14.815032623546891
It is mine.	23.282279161847164
I paid the rent.	16.906247839029827
Now I eat his salt bread.	10.117045638760818
Give him the key too.	11.805946736477816
All.	25.50621404370786
He will ask for it.	6.67495628244433
That was in his eyes.	13.591072276906008
—After all, Haines began...	6.404391889640748
Stephen turned and saw that the cold gaze which had measured him was not all unkind.	23.097302764440613
—After all, I should think you are able to free yourself.	16.98818712812541
You are your own master, it seems to me.	10.416499109415124
—I am a servant of two masters, Stephen said, an English and an Italian.	22.94560526636769
Haines said.	5.46199924432213
A crazy queen, old and jealous.	15.131101928575964
Kneel down before me.	5.850199956097028
—And a third, Stephen said, there is who wants me for odd jobs.	18.023196462241735
Haines said again.	13.640005637436854
What do you mean?	11.839674394825947
Haines detached from his underlip some fibres of tobacco before he spoke.	11.65097143231422
—I can quite understand that, he said calmly.	15.006112377180768
An Irishman must think like that, I daresay.	14.781421877240131
We feel in England that we have treated you rather unfairly.	8.044702123025486
It seems history is to blame.	7.020604065088357
The proud potent titles clanged over Stephen’s memory the triumph of their brazen bells: _et unam sanctam catholicam et apostolicam ecclesiam:_ the slow growth and change of rite and dogma like his own rare thoughts, a chemistry of stars.	6.491387731787817
Symbol of the apostles in the mass for pope Marcellus, the voices blended, singing alone loud in affirmation: and behind their chant the vigilant angel of the church militant disarmed and menaced her heresiarchs.	11.044994752004742
A horde of heresies fleeing with mitres awry: Photius and the brood of mockers of whom Mulligan was one, and Arius, warring his life long upon the consubstantiality of the Son with the Father, and Valentine, spurning Christ’s terrene body, and the subtle African heresiarch Sabellius who held that the Father was Himself His own Son.	9.799413678183937
Words Mulligan had spoken a moment since in mockery to the stranger.	11.953839673458441
Idle mockery.	13.943843522115227
The void awaits surely all them that weave the wind: a menace, a disarming and a worsting from those embattled angels of the church, Michael’s host, who defend her ever in the hour of conflict with their lances and their shields.	14.844033494199273
Hear, hear! Prolonged applause.	5.598066556521952
I don’t want to see my country fall into the hands of German jews either.	10.733522231872223
That’s our national problem, I’m afraid, just now.	9.426048135526395
Two men stood at the verge of the cliff, watching: businessman, boatman.	11.171992045327132
—She’s making for Bullock harbour.	21.242720587833155
The boatman nodded towards the north of the bay with some disdain.	21.307792198702153
—There’s five fathoms out there, he said.	6.584426486529229
It’ll be swept up that way when the tide comes in about one.	14.054174302285332
It’s nine days today.	14.767948498222104
The man that was drowned.	18.17943331799219
A sail veering about the blank bay waiting for a swollen bundle to bob up, roll over to the sun a puffy face, saltwhite.	12.132688422330046
Here I am.	15.646297494290323
They followed the winding path down to the creek.	20.115176529103117
Buck Mulligan stood on a stone, in shirtsleeves, his unclipped tie rippling over his shoulder.	13.056569966777689
A young man clinging to a spur of rock near him, moved slowly frogwise his green legs in the deep jelly of the water.	13.750712180670522
—Is the brother with you, Malachi?	20.812128410177312
—Down in Westmeath.	15.331125603964113
With the Bannons.	19.16681357793786
—Still there?	13.43945876593051

Says he found a sweet young thing down there.	9.45908797508751
Photo girl he calls her.	6.47123433765101
—Snapshot, eh?	4.82999269833261
Brief exposure.	16.58211792698403
Buck Mulligan sat down to unlace his boots.	10.06104074785427
An elderly man shot up near the spur of rock a blowing red face.	5.927272269508815
He scrambled up by the stones, water glistening on his pate and on its garland of grey hair, water rilling over his chest and paunch and spilling jets out of his black sagging loincloth.	12.14928456815071
Buck Mulligan made way for him to scramble past and, glancing at Haines and Stephen, crossed himself piously with his thumbnail at brow and lips and breastbone.	13.656580854003542
—Seymour’s back in town, the young man said, grasping again his spur of rock.	23.22082410970464
Chucked medicine and going in for the army.	17.752866056027344

The father is rotto with money.	6.626536687226258

For Haines’s chapbook.	26.431179229370375
No-one here to hear.	11.656543755534372

What then?	9.573690248878348

Had Pyrrhus not fallen by a beldam’s hand in Argos or Julius Caesar not been knifed to death.	8.924985174651496

A swarthy boy opened a book and propped it nimbly under the breastwork of his satchel.	9.427068974204403
He recited jerks of verse with odd glances at the text: _—Weep no more, woful shepherds, weep no more For Lycidas, your sorrow, is not dead, Sunk though he be beneath the watery floor..._ It must be a movement then, an actuality of the possible as possible.	10.651570207981436
Aristotle’s phrase formed itself within the gabbled verses and floated out into the studious silence of the library of Saint Genevieve where he had read, sheltered from the sin of Paris, night by night.	11.60333229850556
By his elbow a delicate Siamese conned a handbook of strategy.	7.036872919037387
Fed and feeding brains about me: under glowlamps, impaled, with faintly beating feelers: and in my mind’s darkness a sloth of the underworld, reluctant, shy of brightness, shifting her dragon scaly folds.	10.364302109785656
Thought is the thought of thought.	22.763882368833325
Tranquil brightness.	13.943843522115227

Tranquility sudden, vast, candescent: form of forms.	5.4806254342210305

Of him that walked the waves.	7.691457542102005

We give it up.	6.049801959006155

Sargent who alone had lingered came forward slowly, showing an open copybook.	8.373861781548177
His tangled hair and scraggy neck gave witness of unreadiness and through his misty glasses weak eyes looked up pleading.	6.932864146355754
On his cheek, dull and bloodless, a soft stain of ink lay, dateshaped, recent and damp as a snail’s bed.	8.44296215740212
He held out his copybook.	26.899505158037513
The word _Sums_ was written on the headline.	17.65121519328631
Beneath were sloping figures and at the foot a crooked signature with blind loops and a blot.	7.704972284684189
Cyril Sargent: his name and seal.	18.04836957526661
—Mr Deasy told me to write them out all again, he said, and show them to you, sir.	20.540833424831927
Stephen touched the edges of the book.	15.477604128869496
Futility.	32.13581597679176
—Do you understand how to do them now?	17.566067088084672
—Numbers eleven to fifteen, Sargent answered.	4.413007673976454
Mr Deasy said I was to copy them off the board, sir.	16.071229754859544
—Can you do them yourself?	11.5983521447163
—No, sir.	5.04976211744074
Ugly and futile: lean neck and tangled hair and a stain of ink, a snail’s bed.	11.212629470336243
Yet someone had loved him, borne him in her arms and in her heart.	20.265787182273712
But for her the race of the world would have trampled him underfoot, a squashed boneless snail.	24.01611647126627
She had loved his weak watery blood drained from her own.	7.716681871792911
Was that then real?	20.33847581516464
The only true thing in life?	11.996749088100318
His mother’s prostrate body the fiery Columbanus in holy zeal bestrode.	7.317309621992127
She was no more: the trembling skeleton of a twig burnt in the fire, an odour of rosewood and wetted ashes.	20.165415596997384
She had saved him from being trampled underfoot and had gone, scarcely having been.	15.865481832652375
A poor soul gone to heaven: and on a heath beneath winking stars a fox, red reek of rapine in his fur, with merciless bright eyes scraped in the earth, listened, scraped up the earth, listened, scraped and scraped.	10.561086530125378
Sitting at his side Stephen solved out the problem.	15.612910924180161
He proves by algebra that Shakespeare’s ghost is Hamlet’s grandfather.	9.914874219390306
Sargent peered askance through his slanted glasses.	8.079925696362952
Hockeysticks rattled in the lumberroom: the hollow knock of a ball and calls from the field.	29.31836419324761
Across the page the symbols moved in grave morrice, in the mummery of their letters, wearing quaint caps of squares and cubes.	9.278261036160856
Give hands, traverse, bow to partner: so: imps of fancy of the Moors.	9.416258623526355
Gone too from the world, Averroes and Moses Maimonides, dark men in mien and movement, flashing in their mocking mirrors the obscure soul of the world, a darkness shining in brightness which brightness could not comprehend.	10.831413432800215

—Yes, sir.	3.411884148314826

_Amor matris:_ subjective and objective genitive.	11.303343629405108
With her weak blood and wheysour milk she had fed him and hid from sight of others his swaddling bands.	8.854115438144717
Like him was I, these sloping shoulders, this gracelessness.	18.390525684474287
My childhood bends beside me.	4.247841964681215
Too far for me to lay a hand there once or lightly.	15.189965021140353
Mine is far and his secret as our eyes.	11.109943570392652
Secrets, silent, stony sit in the dark palaces of both our hearts: secrets weary of their tyranny: tyrants, willing to be dethroned.	8.974452639837681

As it was in the beginning, is now.	18.968685054118655
On the sideboard the tray of Stuart coins, base treasure of a bog: and ever shall be.	11.127592777203416
And snug in their spooncase of purple plush, faded, the twelve apostles having preached to all the gentiles: world without end.	8.590790521491156

Symbols too of beauty and of power.	18.41934307033811

Three times now.	6.724720173082869
Well?	17.685021073205338
I can break them in this instant if I will.	24.806751008202827

Money is power.	8.080465848484218
When you have lived as long as I have.	15.53044115562018
I know, I know.	13.261501263434598

He lifted his gaze from the idle shells to the old man’s stare.	26.230117875914218

Do you know what is the pride of the English?	26.12060743086233

His seacold eyes looked on the empty bay: it seems history is to blame: on me and on my words, unhating.	17.536917863156585

Mr Deasy stared sternly for some moments over the mantelpiece at the shapely bulk of a man in tartan fillibegs: Albert Edward, prince of Wales.	12.920441870548776
—You think me an old fogey and an old tory, his thoughtful voice said.	13.221746504457997
I saw three generations since O’Connell’s time.	12.715246137989677
I remember the famine in ’46.	9.50898889582664
Do you know that the orange lodges agitated for repeal of the union twenty years before O’Connell did or before the prelates of your communion denounced him as a demagogue?	13.56072867909664
You fenians forget some things.	5.028291818418275
Glorious, pious and immortal memory.	6.062520842810636
The lodge of Diamond in Armagh the splendid behung with corpses of papishes.	4.101978546749398
Hoarse, masked and armed, the planters’ covenant.	11.002821868865341
The black north and true blue bible.	9.926461765363332
Croppies lie down.	5.669497175335421
Stephen sketched a brief gesture.	11.296873571782095
—I have rebel blood in me too, Mr Deasy said.	10.588516959556918
On the spindle side.	12.000312834358382
But I am descended from sir John Blackwood who voted for the union.	20.954461187900623
We are all Irish, all kings’ sons.	13.823819061590184
—Alas, Stephen said.	3.0452396092909093
—_Per vias rectas_, Mr Deasy said firmly, was his motto.	12.337292732388866
He voted for it and put on his topboots to ride to Dublin from the Ards of Down to do so.	14.281796072595958
Lal the ral the ra The rocky road to Dublin.	5.857009397755579
A gruff squire on horseback with shiny topboots.	5.039775617670823
Soft day, sir John! Soft day, your honour!...	4.527637153435295
Day!...	2.201367084227408
Day!...	2.201367084227408
Two topboots jog dangling on to Dublin.	7.6869423498313365
Lal the ral the ra.	8.68745168372438
Lal the ral the raddy.	8.03835114938011
—That reminds me, Mr Deasy said.	7.119735380986374
You can do me a favour, Mr Dedalus, with some of your literary friends.	56.1343111026689
I have a letter here for the press.	32.56905214992466
Sit down a moment.	14.374293332989946
I have just to copy the end.	15.588131509286464
He went to the desk near the window, pulled in his chair twice and read off some words from the sheet on the drum of his typewriter.	27.42431553304242
—Sit down.	5.521842410738406
Excuse me, he said over his shoulder, _the dictates of common sense._ Just a moment.	8.374283533755085
He peered from under his shaggy brows at the manuscript by his elbow and, muttering, began to prod the stiff buttons of the keyboard slowly, sometimes blowing as he screwed up the drum to erase an error.	13.779885683393104
Stephen seated himself noiselessly before the princely presence.	8.611398535667501
Framed around the walls images of vanished horses stood in homage, their meek heads poised in air: lord Hastings’ _Repulse_, the duke of Westminster’s _Shotover_, the duke of Beaufort’s _Ceylon_, _prix de Paris_, 1866.	9.46160267896149
Elfin riders sat them, watchful of a sign.	16.136850741167923
He saw their speeds, backing king’s colours, and shouted with the shouts of vanished crowds.	13.728064625256305
—Full stop, Mr Deasy bade his keys.	13.079851521179535
_But prompt ventilation of this allimportant question..._ Where Cranly led me to get rich quick, hunting his winners among the mudsplashed brakes, amid the bawls of bookies on their pitches and reek of the canteen, over the motley slush.	10.724074769600946
Dicers and thimbleriggers we hurried by after the hoofs, the vying caps and jackets and past the meatfaced woman, a butcher’s dame, nuzzling thirstily her clove of orange.	9.941814739218874
Shouts rang shrill from the boys’ playfield and a whirring whistle.	15.102092558543127
Again: a goal.	17.069946159397386
I am among them, among their battling bodies in a medley, the joust of life.	13.930267879172266
You mean that knockkneed mother’s darling who seems to be slightly crawsick?	12.061432575647522
Jousts.	32.13581597679176
Time shocked rebounds, shock by shock.	5.0965544461928545
Jousts, slush and uproar of battles, the frozen deathspew of the slain, a shout of spearspikes baited with men’s bloodied guts.	13.742276903226806
—Now then, Mr Deasy said, rising.	17.09140402873424
He came to the table, pinning together his sheets.	10.932887014673238
Stephen stood up.	5.274946864842512
—I have put the matter into a nutshell, Mr Deasy said.	14.809526492143789
It’s about the foot and mouth disease.	12.276986051674896
Just look through it.	5.231153914616817
There can be no two opinions on the matter.	14.293398481539416
May I trespass on your valuable space.	8.824572099411686
That doctrine of _laissez faire_ which so often in our history.	6.559823102274001
Our cattle trade.	8.080465848484218
The way of all our old industries.	24.74694449812217
Liverpool ring which jockeyed the Galway harbour scheme.	5.584689593138076
European conflagration.	16.58211792698403

Pardoned a classical allusion.	8.55639188197318
Cassandra.	32.13581597679176
By a woman who was no better than she should be.	10.0874439819839
To come to the point at issue.	19.541411167412004

Foot and mouth disease.	6.691843718401972
Known as Koch’s preparation.	19.455884189298065
Serum and virus.	11.148858409578036

Rinderpest.	32.13581597679176
Emperor’s horses at Mürzsteg, lower Austria.	11.17338447272231

Mr Henry Blackwood Price.	10.82639741088797
Courteous offer a fair trial.	7.38730553118868
Dictates of common sense.	9.014958998660607
Allimportant question.	9.105249025485831
Thanking you for the hospitality of your columns.	19.631083458535752
You will see at the next outbreak they will put an embargo on Irish cattle.	12.369037846692887
And it can be cured.	21.80361640680111
It is cured.	29.368544992620652
My cousin, Blackwood Price, writes to me it is regularly treated and cured in Austria by cattledoctors there.	6.6175352885372085
They offer to come over here.	7.464710413027684
I am trying to work up influence with the department.	19.96306112879539
Now I’m going to try publicity.	16.531858853258534
I am surrounded by difficulties, by...	10.004653570898402
intrigues by...	3.624412641305564
backstairs influence by...	3.39180688408973
He raised his forefinger and beat the air oldly before his voice spoke.	13.429748296517198
—Mark my words, Mr Dedalus, he said.	27.69148679840795
England is in the hands of the jews.	29.1347134602807
In all the highest places: her finance, her press.	19.262545909947455
And they are the signs of a nation’s decay.	37.79413552244187
Wherever they gather they eat up the nation’s vital strength.	12.247032073599176
I have seen it coming these years.	10.96033800484188
As sure as we are standing here the jew merchants are already at their work of destruction.	13.880752453109041
Old England is dying.	8.592917319534681
He stepped swiftly off, his eyes coming to blue life as they passed a broad sunbeam.	15.107808699955596
—Dying, he said again, if not dead by now.	10.083158376056845
The harlot’s cry from street to street Shall weave old England’s windingsheet.	7.241588848994059
His eyes open wide in vision stared sternly across the sunbeam in which he halted.	12.430632789522798

—They sinned against the light, Mr Deasy said gravely.	20.003399041178444
And you can see the darkness in their eyes.	23.790247967557754
On the steps of the Paris stock exchange the goldskinned men quoting prices on their gemmed fingers.	7.512675179812894
Gabble of geese.	7.791124599957709
They swarmed loud, uncouth about the temple, their heads thickplotting under maladroit silk hats.	9.285507473333247
Not theirs: these clothes, this speech, these gestures.	9.410120302125758
Their full slow eyes belied the words, the gestures eager and unoffending, but knew the rancours massed about them and knew their zeal was vain.	9.307497706344837
Vain patience to heap and hoard.	5.636211105707435
Time surely would scatter all.	3.965268253004198
A hoard heaped by the roadside: plundered and passing on.	5.666330730292452
Their eyes knew their years of wandering and, patient, knew the dishonours of their flesh.	11.008563371004364

Stephen said.	4.142530577726673

Mr Deasy asked.	9.651153501825009

Is this old wisdom?	15.331125603964113

Mr Deasy asked.	9.651153501825009

Looking up again he set them free.	11.561733687045736
—I am happier than you are, he said.	8.430759677622886
We have committed many errors and many sins.	8.163952900102624
A woman brought sin into the world.	4.9181448762793805
For a woman who was no better than she should be, Helen, the runaway wife of Menelaus, ten years the Greeks made war on Troy.	11.840583620598183
A faithless wife first brought the strangers to our shore here, MacMurrough’s wife and her leman, O’Rourke, prince of Breffni.	10.793912318715677
A woman too brought Parnell low.	8.622756692332196
Many errors, many failures but not the one sin.	12.471868853069187
I am a struggler now at the end of my days.	13.91034679148884
But I will fight for the right till the end.	41.51598651557793
For Ulster will fight And Ulster will be right.	7.477474848336423

That’s why.	17.070924675557535

[ 3 ] Ineluctable modality of the visible: at least that if no more, thought through my eyes.	15.428651357172821

Go easy.	12.599684944605478

Limit of the diaphane in.	13.080333122494746
Why in?	12.599684944605478
Diaphane, adiaphane.	9.70564496856689
If you can put your five fingers through it it is a gate, if not a door.	22.047455457408347
Shut your eyes and see.	11.47076225801574
You are walking through it howsomever.	14.039888438850488
I am, a stride at a time.	16.837251801443273

Open your eyes.	9.774053531395007
No. Jesus! If I fell over a cliff that beetles o’er his base, fell through the _nebeneinander_ ineluctably! I am getting on nicely in the dark.	10.08404802116395
My ash sword hangs at my side.	6.290255561264375
Tap with it: they do.	14.00250689294661

— II — [ 4 ] Mr Leopold Bloom ate with relish the inner organs of beasts and fowls.	7.055749573220017
He liked thick giblet soup, nutty gizzards, a stuffed roast heart, liverslices fried with crustcrumbs, fried hencods’ roes.	6.739910021037791

Gelid light and air were in the kitchen but out of doors gentle summer morning everywhere.	10.499842143974137
Made him feel a bit peckish.	22.742392611269942
The coals were reddening.	8.55639188197318

Wait for an opportunity.	27.527975593893785
All waited.	9.712135624511834

A jolt.	16.58211792698403

Tritonville road.	11.992428326154721
Quicker.	32.13581597679176

Brunswick street.	11.045865395615886

Respect.	32.13581597679176

Mr Dedalus said, stretching over across.	12.076821017328216
The carriage, passing the open drains and mounds of rippedup roadway before the tenement houses, lurched round the corner and, swerving back to the tramtrack, rolled on noisily with chattering wheels.	9.955222050023568
Mr Dedalus fell back, saying: —Was that Mulligan cad with him?	18.073178090130202
His _fidus Achates_! —No, Mr Bloom said.	5.58268817759147
He was alone.	17.589279053854323
—Down with his aunt Sally, I suppose, Mr Dedalus said, the Goulding faction, the drunken little costdrawer and Crissie, papa’s little lump of dung, the wise child that knows her own father.	18.461548273718098
Mr Bloom smiled joylessly on Ringsend road.	8.131894904483678
Wallace Bros: the bottleworks: Dodder bridge.	7.216179363145407
Richie Goulding and the legal bag.	41.327452264200076
Goulding, Collis and Ward he calls the firm.	8.983702204370905
His jokes are getting a bit damp.	10.65498217888351
Great card he was.	7.73885634873165
Waltzing in Stamer street with Ignatius Gallaher on a Sunday morning, the landlady’s two hats pinned on his head.	12.809433830215719
Out on the rampage all night.	15.30830572397579
Beginning to tell on him now: that backache of his, I fear.	23.704007115861653
Wife ironing his back.	5.277409504723383
Thinks he’ll cure it with pills.	13.455226193843671
All breadcrumbs they are.	6.0533171231034855
About six hundred per cent profit.	10.886284035956425
—He’s in with a lowdown crowd, Mr Dedalus snarled.	72.16738227360834
That Mulligan is a contaminated bloody doubledyed ruffian by all accounts.	10.210070114932666
His name stinks all over Dublin.	12.818324587100369
But with the help of God and His blessed mother I’ll make it my business to write a letter one of those days to his mother or his aunt or whatever she is that will open her eye as wide as a gate.	18.499860993379848
I’ll tickle his catastrophe, believe you me.	5.506236726575048
He cried above the clatter of the wheels: —I won’t have her bastard of a nephew ruin my son.	11.339129892315935
A counterjumper’s son.	8.870015585463426
Selling tapes in my cousin, Peter Paul M’Swiney’s.	11.36938321582179
Not likely.	10.269333115996188
He ceased.	16.688409521161915

Full of his son.	20.975021413123347
He is right.	13.937537050260646

My son.	11.458079205252007
Me in his eyes.	7.054374891265032

From me.	6.777985144107338

And the sergeant grinning up.	7.569341078144219

Gasworks.	32.13581597679176

Isn’t it awfully good?	7.817631027741135

—Drown Barabbas! Mr Dedalus cried.	6.332242459653635

—No, Mr Bloom said, the son himself.....	7.542537227943652
Martin Cunningham thwarted his speech rudely: —Reuben J and the son were piking it down the quay next the river on their way to the Isle of Man boat and the young chiseller suddenly got loose and over the wall with him into the Liffey.	17.254432869861642
—For God’s sake! Mr Dedalus exclaimed in fright.	19.39911789668545
Is he dead?	17.250245446836605
—Dead! Martin Cunningham cried.	9.273869893919226
Not he! A boatman got a pole and fished him out by the slack of the breeches and he was landed up to the father on the quay more dead than alive.	17.041344713017654
Half the town was there.	10.350859524394833
But the funny part is.....	4.777478938313649

—O, he did, Martin Cunningham affirmed.	24.11082975125138
Like a hero.	26.31056454048006
—Isn’t it awfully good?	6.3766602931465375
Mr Bloom said eagerly.	14.246913416933495

Mr Power’s choked laugh burst quietly in the carriage.	16.65714950077506
Nelson’s pillar.	15.6120492026812
—Eight plums a penny! Eight for a penny! —We had better look a little serious, Martin Cunningham said.	7.652953748054835
Mr Dedalus sighed.	28.707870938960482
—Ah then indeed, he said, poor little Paddy wouldn’t grudge us a laugh.	15.797903568060672

Dead meat trade.	8.080465848484218

John Henry is not the worst in the world.	21.991199426688503
—How did he lose it?	17.994787128758915
Ned Lambert asked.	6.973779479054919
Liquor, what?	7.277966954207259
—Many a good man’s fault, Mr Dedalus said with a sigh.	48.203756630300795
They halted about the door of the mortuary chapel.	24.7887637936353
Poor boy! Was he there when the father?	18.526679434404677
Both unconscious.	13.943843522115227
Lighten up at the last moment and recognise for the last time.	11.031253998658732
All he might have done.	16.863687054878447
I owe three shillings to O’Grady.	19.659522166590516
Would he understand?	12.872306092276881
The mutes bore the coffin into the chapel.	17.27789004370941
Which end is his head?	21.460887099020365
After a moment he followed the others in, blinking in the screened light.	23.88151646897723
The coffin lay on its bier before the chancel, four tall yellow candles at its corners.	9.023114230578036
Always in front of us.	9.060263187360558
Corny Kelleher, laying a wreath at each fore corner, beckoned to the boy to kneel.	14.083257977996029
The mourners knelt here and there in prayingdesks.	11.749712715539223
Mr Bloom stood behind near the font and, when all had knelt, dropped carefully his unfolded newspaper from his pocket and knelt his right knee upon it.	8.764585692596743
He fitted his black hat gently on his left knee and, holding its brim, bent over piously.	10.007673280975322
A server bearing a brass bucket with something in it came out through a door.	14.88904935602664
The whitesmocked priest came after him, tidying his stole with one hand, balancing with the other a little book against his toad’s belly.	15.313880929894689
Who’ll read the book?	33.68233749978552
I, said the rook.	31.487583474062607
They halted by the bier and the priest began to read out of his book with a fluent croak.	27.160976405930064
I knew his name was like a coffin.	21.612389434573153
_Dominenamine._ Bully about the muzzle he looks.	12.494284429804933
Bosses the show.	6.4345972758613375
Muscular christian.	16.58211792698403
Woe betide anyone that looks crooked at him: priest.	8.331296182346096
Thou art Peter.	14.734401266318299
Burst sideways like a sheep in clover Dedalus says he will.	14.952616335004766
With a belly on him like a poisoned pup.	19.737341678215117
Most amusing expressions that man finds.	9.873367461884873
Hhhn: burst sideways.	7.124763581548046
_—Non intres in judicium cum servo tuo, Domine._ Makes them feel more important to be prayed over in Latin.	7.81839801539644
Requiem mass.	11.089130599646298
Crape weepers.	16.58211792698403
Blackedged notepaper.	16.58211792698403
Your name on the altarlist.	30.374174614250677
Chilly place this.	6.486525774962426
Want to feed well, sitting in there all the morning in the gloom kicking his heels waiting for the next please.	27.13254977729318
Eyes of a toad too.	10.339205757032468
What swells him up that way?	13.602342912782763
Molly gets swelled after cabbage.	7.108476678798343
Air of the place maybe.	28.846839900721175
Looks full up of bad gas.	11.188463824301515
Must be an infernal lot of bad gas round the place.	14.186544409647103
Butchers, for instance: they get like raw beefsteaks.	15.972251052739136
Who was telling me?	6.663853890911756
Mervyn Browne.	16.58211792698403
Down in the vaults of saint Werburgh’s lovely old organ hundred and fifty they have to bore a hole in the coffins sometimes to let out the bad gas and burn it.	12.76739313904979
Out it rushes: blue.	6.053836374621549
One whiff of that and you’re a goner.	15.154920165915929
My kneecap is hurting me.	3.4719550638859062
Ow. That’s better.	17.071421901122807
The priest took a stick with a knob at the end of it out of the boy’s bucket and shook it over the coffin.	20.983853661057438
Then he walked to the other end and shook it again.	18.14026277132683
Then he came back and put it back in the bucket.	15.664741401565783
As you were before you rested.	20.70450453733763
It’s all written down: he has to do it.	12.238875241412057
_—Et ne nos inducas in tentationem._ The server piped the answers in the treble.	10.364224230082268
I often thought it would be better to have boy servants.	14.132756054598135
Up to fifteen or so.	12.593403768132497
After that, of course ...	8.094321652385174
Holy water that was, I expect.	16.383670752309218
Shaking sleep out of it.	4.585328916152403
He must be fed up with that job, shaking that thing over all the corpses they trot up.	11.488643395687252
What harm if he could see what he was shaking it over.	15.069032383243092
All the year round he prayed the same thing over them all and shook water on top of them: sleep.	22.543265191850946
On Dignam now.	4.429616469187592
_—In paradisum._ Said he was going to paradise or is in paradise.	18.941589426183683
Says that over everybody.	7.622878559556313
Tiresome kind of a job.	17.622683140600582
But he has to say something.	32.26782959596036
The priest closed his book and went off, followed by the server.	21.577760046733133
Corny Kelleher opened the sidedoors and the gravediggers came in, hoisted the coffin again, carried it out and shoved it on their cart.	21.331326848183032
Corny Kelleher gave one wreath to the boy and one to the brother-in-law.	11.918988804971896
All followed them out of the sidedoors into the mild grey air.	14.40322066243603
Mr Bloom came last folding his paper again into his pocket.	8.576640258556191
He gazed gravely at the ground till the coffincart wheeled off to the left.	18.640444654975436
The metal wheels ground the gravel with a sharp grating cry and the pack of blunt boots followed the trundled barrow along a lane of sepulchres.	9.039913220940354
The ree the ra the ree the ra the roo.	5.59876783362569
Lord, I mustn’t lilt here.	15.814634865350284
—The O’Connell circle, Mr Dedalus said about him.	55.65734751224438
Mr Power’s soft eyes went up to the apex of the lofty cone.	22.165465168361642
—He’s at rest, he said, in the middle of his people, old Dan O’.	19.483533092842837
But his heart is buried in Rome.	14.806358835734887
How many broken hearts are buried here, Simon! —Her grave is over there, Jack, Mr Dedalus said.	21.960360645697858
I’ll soon be stretched beside her.	9.499582448053319
Let Him take me whenever He likes.	8.701344767030145

Mr Power took his arm.	20.54618757567353

Mr Kernan said with reproof.	16.393027587942676

Secret eyes, secretsearching.	18.401354546352948

We are the last.	17.63420523885456

The resurrection and the life.	17.2829582964391

—My dear Simon, the caretaker answered in a low voice.	16.236947199570917
I don’t want your custom at all.	6.593422784912635

—Did you hear that one, he asked them, about Mulcahy from the Coombe?	30.510790561851657
—I did not, Martin Cunningham said.	8.460724307512764
They bent their silk hats in concert and Hynes inclined his ear.	4.635922348830029
The caretaker hung his thumbs in the loops of his gold watchchain and spoke in a discreet tone to their vacant smiles.	14.818657611201782
—They tell the story, he said, that two drunks came out here one foggy evening to look for the grave of a friend of theirs.	18.473740467270893
They asked for Mulcahy from the Coombe and were told where he was buried.	16.0661531117462
After traipsing about in the fog they found the grave sure enough.	13.750496692636203
One of the drunks spelt out the name: Terence Mulcahy.	21.3782239123454
The other drunk was blinking up at a statue of Our Saviour the widow had got put up.	10.65475967380398
The caretaker blinked up at one of the sepulchres they passed.	22.16961161875083
He resumed: —And, after blinking up at the sacred figure, _Not a bloody bit like the man_, says he.	11.353659098306581
_That’s not Mulcahy_, says he, _whoever done it_.	11.170463399027705
Rewarded by smiles he fell back and spoke with Corny Kelleher, accepting the dockets given him, turning them over and scanning them as he walked.	12.039334533946498
—That’s all done with a purpose, Martin Cunningham explained to Hynes.	18.04011651263181
—I know, Hynes said.	7.265351311442401
I know that.	11.797357496708818

—It was the speech, mark you, the professor said, of a finished orator, full of courteous haughtiness and pouring in chastened diction I will not say the vials of his wrath but pouring the proud man’s contumely upon the new movement.	14.056574890624695
It was then a new movement.	27.789746153044394
We were weak, therefore worthless.	11.032716500795994
He closed his long thin lips an instant but, eager to be on, raised an outspanned hand to his spectacles and, with trembling thumb and ringfinger touching lightly the black rims, steadied them to a new focus.	13.540866177752902
IMPROMPTU In ferial tone he addressed J.	4.259879087680909
O’Molloy: —Taylor had come there, you must know, from a sickbed.	20.476221372072647

His dark lean face had a growth of shaggy beard round it.	5.777124307164343

O’Molloy’s towards Stephen’s face and then bent at once to the ground, seeking.	20.181891331591764
His unglazed linen collar appeared behind his bent head, soiled by his withering hair.	7.63883704480051

He raised his head firmly.	18.030907531253433
His eyes bethought themselves once more.	10.325456014214856
He began: _—Mr Chairman, ladies and gentlemen: Great was my admiration in listening to the remarks addressed to the youth of Ireland a moment since by my learned friend.	9.71005300773358
It seemed to me that I had been transported into a country far away from this country, into an age remote from this age, that I stood in ancient Egypt and that I was listening to the speech of some highpriest of that land addressed to the youthful Moses._ His listeners held their cigarettes poised to hear, their smokes ascending in frail stalks that flowered with his speech.	16.243095792517433
_And let our crooked smokes._ Noble words coming.	4.330667167500065
Look out.	5.885791345035451
Could you try your hand at it yourself?	19.30036640965656
_—And it seemed to me that I heard the voice of that Egyptian highpriest raised in a tone of like haughtiness and like pride.	14.123942540142052
I heard his words and their meaning was revealed to me._ FROM THE FATHERS It was revealed to me that those things are good which yet are corrupted which neither if they were supremely good nor unless they were good could be corrupted.	10.715817853947515
Ah, curse you! That’s saint Augustine.	22.80003086901755
_—Why will you jews not accept our culture, our religion and our language?	14.017259444339336
You are a tribe of nomad herdsmen: we are a mighty people.	11.753836205505067
You have no cities nor no wealth: our cities are hives of humanity and our galleys, trireme and quadrireme, laden with all manner merchandise furrow the waters of the known globe.	6.754227958880461
You have but emerged from primitive conditions: we have a literature, a priesthood, an agelong history and a polity._ Nile.	14.207288850564865
Child, man, effigy.	15.702315260620544
By the Nilebank the babemaries kneel, cradle of bulrushes: a man supple in combat: stonehorned, stonebearded, heart of stone.	7.137145018977675
_—You pray to a local and obscure idol: our temples, majestic and mysterious, are the abodes of Isis and Osiris, of Horus and Ammon Ra. Yours serfdom, awe and humbleness: ours thunder and the seas.	6.481102227333678
Israel is weak and few are her children: Egypt is an host and terrible are her arms.	7.398631385879144
Vagrants and daylabourers are you called: the world trembles at our name._ A dumb belch of hunger cleft his speech.	10.016593654429965
He lifted his voice above it boldly: _—But, ladies and gentlemen, had the youthful Moses listened to and accepted that view of life, had he bowed his head and bowed his will and bowed his spirit before that arrogant admonition he would never have brought the chosen people out of their house of bondage, nor followed the pillar of the cloud by day.	12.357087222428682
He would never have spoken with the Eternal amid lightnings on Sinai’s mountaintop nor ever have come down with the light of inspiration shining in his countenance and bearing in his arms the tables of the law, graven in the language of the outlaw._ He ceased and looked at them, enjoying a silence.	12.822900353649151
