Ignatius Loyola, make haste to help me! —The play begins.	16.10947396177671
A player comes on under the shadow, made up in the castoff mail of a court buck, a wellset man with a bass voice.	18.051320479641536
It is the ghost, the king, a king and no king, and the player is Shakespeare who has studied _Hamlet_ all the years of his life which were not vanity in order to play the part of the spectre.	25.471128473952717
He speaks the words to Burbage, the young player who stands before him beyond the rack of cerecloth, calling him by a name: Hamlet, I am thy father’s spirit, bidding him list.	12.4075292451717
To a son he speaks, the son of his soul, the prince, young Hamlet and to the son of his body, Hamnet Shakespeare, who has died in Stratford that his namesake may live for ever.	14.765535979747368
Is it possible that that player Shakespeare, a ghost by absence, and in the vesture of buried Denmark, a ghost by death, speaking his own words to his own son’s name (had Hamnet Shakespeare lived he would have been prince Hamlet’s twin), is it possible, I want to know, or probable that he did not draw or foresee the logical conclusion of those premises: you are the dispossessed son: I am the murdered father: your mother is the guilty queen, Ann Shakespeare, born Hathaway?	15.987418090330092

—As we, or mother Dana, weave and unweave our bodies, Stephen said, from day to day, their molecules shuttled to and fro, so does the artist weave and unweave his image.	9.267523806655007
And as the mole on my right breast is where it was when I was born, though all my body has been woven of new stuff time after time, so through the ghost of the unquiet father the image of the unliving son looks forth.	19.122515166449897
In the intense instant of imagination, when the mind, Shelley says, is a fading coal, that which I was is that which I am and that which in possibility I may come to be.	20.19810357057561
So in the future, the sister of the past, I may see myself as I sit here now but by reflection from that which then I shall be.	19.337743994761695

Why?	12.497976142926124

He was overborne in a cornfield first (ryefield, I should say) and he will never be a victor in his own eyes after nor play victoriously the game of laugh and lie down.	11.189083533744729

A like fate awaits him and the two rages commingle in a whirlpool.	12.311911550472669
They list.	10.269333115996188
And in the porches of their ears I pour.	19.69203210529304
—The soul has been before stricken mortally, a poison poured in the porch of a sleeping ear.	19.758540956683394
But those who are done to death in sleep cannot know the manner of their quell unless their Creator endow their souls with that knowledge in the life to come.	13.508734898004436
The poisoning and the beast with two backs that urged it King Hamlet’s ghost could not know of were he not endowed with knowledge by his creator.	11.008706390753716
Ravisher and ravished, what he would but would not, go with him from Lucrece’s bluecircled ivory globes to Imogen’s breast, bare, with its mole cinquespotted.	19.612803605910855
He goes back, weary of the creation he has piled up to hide him from himself, an old dog licking an old sore.	20.236768869864825
But, because loss is his gain, he passes on towards eternity in undiminished personality, untaught by the wisdom he has written or by the laws he has revealed.	15.870838874078075
His beaver is up.	5.813153198135091
He is a ghost, a shadow now, the wind by Elsinore’s rocks or what you will, the sea’s voice, a voice heard only in the heart of him who is the substance of his shadow, the son consubstantial with the father.	42.75814662581822

He Who Himself begot middler the Holy Ghost and Himself sent Himself, Agenbuyer, between Himself and others, Who, put upon by His fiends, stripped and whipped, was nailed like bat to barndoor, starved on crosstree, Who let Him bury, stood up, harrowed hell, fared into heaven and there these nineteen hundred years sitteth on the right hand of His Own Self but yet shall come in the latter day to doom the quick and dead when all the quick shall be dead already.	7.499635573294081

Shylock chimes with the jewbaiting that followed the hanging and quartering of the queen’s leech Lopez, his jew’s heart being plucked forth while the sheeny was yet alive: _Hamlet_ and _Macbeth_ with the coming to the throne of a Scotch philosophaster with a turn for witchroasting.	13.261791318410177

The note of banishment, banishment from the heart, banishment from home, sounds uninterruptedly from _The Two Gentlemen of Verona_ onward till Prospero breaks his staff, buries it certain fathoms in the earth and drowns his book.	6.266295467419791
It doubles itself in the middle of his life, reflects itself in another, repeats itself, protasis, epitasis, catastasis, catastrophe.	10.92157229074425

The playwright who wrote the folio of this world and wrote it badly (He gave us light first and the sun two days later), the lord of things as they are whom the most Roman of catholics call _dio boia_, hangman god, is doubtless all in all in all of us, ostler and butcher, and would be bawd and cuckold too but that in the economy of heaven, foretold by Hamlet, there are no more marriages, glorified man, an androgynous angel, being a wife unto himself.	13.07462549023208

He thought, but not for long, of soldiers and sailors, whose legs had been shot off by cannonballs, ending their days in some pauper ward, and of cardinal Wolsey’s words: _If I had served my God as I have served my king He would not have abandoned me in my old days._ He walked by the treeshade of sunnywinking leaves: and towards him came the wife of Mr David Sheehy M.P. —Very well, indeed, father.	14.606196026415512

It was idyllic: and Father Conmee reflected on the providence of the Creator who had made turf to be in bogs whence men might dig it out and bring it to town and hamlet to make fires in the houses of poor people.	16.98865955245101

At Newcomen bridge Father Conmee stepped into an outward bound tram for he disliked to traverse on foot the dingy way past Mud Island.	8.73485393268222
Father Conmee sat in a corner of the tramcar, a blue ticket tucked with care in the eye of one plump kid glove, while four shillings, a sixpence and five pennies chuted from his other plump glovepalm into his purse.	15.72862868370935
Passing the ivy church he reflected that the ticket inspector usually made his visit when one had carelessly thrown away the ticket.	6.950512080250646

The conductor pulled the bellstrap to stay the car for her.	6.3331657605297655
She passed out with her basket and a marketnet: and Father Conmee saw the conductor help her and net and basket down: and Father Conmee thought that, as she had nearly passed the end of the penny fare, she was one of those good souls who had always to be told twice _bless you, my child,_ that they have been absolved, _pray for me._ But they had so many worries in life, so many cares, poor creatures.	13.648032161263561
From the hoardings Mr Eugene Stratton grimaced with thick niggerlips at Father Conmee.	8.253037593677455
Father Conmee thought of the souls of black and brown and yellow men and of his sermon on saint Peter Claver S.	9.51189351073229
and the African mission and of the propagation of the faith and of the millions of black and brown and yellow souls that had not received the baptism of water when their last hour came like a thief in the night.	15.664300997682998
That book by the Belgian jesuit, _Le Nombre des Élus,_ seemed to Father Conmee a reasonable plea.	8.573305149478372
Those were millions of human souls created by God in His Own likeness to whom the faith had not (D.V.) been brought.	14.54496456461251
But they were God’s souls, created by God.	17.135131830838095

A listless lady, no more young, walked alone the shore of lough Ennel, Mary, first countess of Belvedere, listlessly walking in the evening, not startled when an otter plunged.	9.107060186574461

Don John Conmee walked and moved in times of yore.	12.89468744167807
He was humane and honoured there.	6.502184925777874

It was a charming day.	17.39519718067432

Nones.	32.13581597679176

But lady Maxwell had come.	6.414908858093863

_Deus in adiutorium._ He walked calmly and read mutely the nones, walking and reading till he came to _Res_ in _Beati immaculati: Principium verborum tuorum veritas: in eternum omnia iudicia iustitiæ tuæ._ A flushed young man came from a gap of a hedge and after him came a young woman with wild nodding daisies in her hand.	8.889550609516835
The young man raised his cap abruptly: the young woman abruptly bent and with slow care detached from her light skirt a clinging twig.	8.820980358819876
Father Conmee blessed both gravely and turned a thin page of his breviary.	16.73003101440478
_Sin: Principes persecuti sunt me gratis: et a verbis tuis formidavit cor meum._ * * * Corny Kelleher closed his long daybook and glanced with his drooping eye at a pine coffinlid sentried in a corner.	7.0750838128874705
He pulled himself erect, went to it and, spinning it on its axle, viewed its shape and brass furnishings.	13.005071589229212
Chewing his blade of hay he laid the coffinlid by and came to the doorway.	9.577410564439203
There he tilted his hatbrim to give shade to his eyes and leaned against the doorcase, looking idly out.	11.740255604051816
Father John Conmee stepped into the Dollymount tram on Newcomen bridge.	8.791219894964367

—That’s a fine day, Mr Kelleher.	17.55389872261931

Corny Kelleher sped a silent jet of hayjuice arching from his mouth while a generous white arm from a window in Eccles street flung forth a coin.	8.686365492192415
—What’s the best news?	9.483821459605483
—I seen that particular party last evening, the constable said with bated breath.	14.044178497863816
* * * A onelegged sailor crutched himself round MacConnell’s corner, skirting Rabaiotti’s icecream car, and jerked himself up Eccles street.	9.621545592095373
He swung himself violently forward past Katey and Boody Dedalus, halted and growled: —_home and beauty._ J.	5.640816013512932
O’Molloy’s white careworn face was told that Mr Lambert was in the warehouse with a visitor.	18.08893223206957
A stout lady stopped, took a copper coin from her purse and dropped it into the cap held out to her.	8.227259514140966
The sailor grumbled thanks, glanced sourly at the unheeding windows, sank his head and swung himself forward four strides.	9.08954335710303
He halted and growled angrily: —_For England_...	6.191141426882621
Two barefoot urchins, sucking long liquorice laces, halted near him, gaping at his stump with their yellowslobbered mouths.	10.821949963408622
He swung himself forward in vigorous jerks, halted, lifted his head towards a window and bayed deeply: —_home and beauty._ The gay sweet chirping whistling within went on a bar or two, ceased.	9.675285487243665

Bloom and Chris Callinan were on one side of the car and I was with the wife on the other.	23.08547275839089

Like that.	5.4945867608175005

Know what I mean?	10.797027208721033
His hands moulded ample curves of air.	7.957316905298357
He shut his eyes tight in delight, his body shrinking, and blew a sweet chirp from his lips.	13.913246395701336
—The lad stood to attention anyhow, he said with a sigh.	14.012110619784647
She’s a gamey mare and no mistake.	12.674441034889155
Bloom was pointing out all the stars and the comets in the heavens to Chris Callinan and the jarvey: the great bear and Hercules and the dragon, and the whole jingbang lot.	20.860002731472406
But, by God, I was lost, so to speak, in the milky way.	15.145835903193815
He knows them all, faith.	13.32736253124711
At last she spotted a weeny weeshy one miles away.	4.920352235768857
By God, she had Bloom cornered.	2.4805814210287105
_That one, is it?_ says Chris Callinan, _sure that’s only what you might call a pinprick._ By God, he wasn’t far wide of the mark.	17.889019693763142
Lenehan stopped and leaned on the riverwall, panting with soft laughter.	9.768296183865202
—I’m weak, he gasped.	25.09477644913506
M’Coy’s white face smiled about it at instants and grew grave.	10.011328211109142
Lenehan walked on again.	7.009008609037043
He lifted his yachtingcap and scratched his hindhead rapidly.	6.611088323070501
He glanced sideways in the sunlight at M’Coy.	16.132122265371297
He’s not one of your common or garden...	9.119745451740743
you know...	7.778799062649657
There’s a touch of the artist about old Bloom.	15.603953190051836
* * * Mr Bloom turned over idly pages of _The Awful Disclosures of Maria Monk_, then of Aristotle’s _Masterpiece._ Crooked botched print.	10.437624815197832
Plates: infants cuddled in a ball in bloodred wombs like livers of slaughtered cows.	5.801953700002198
Lots of them like that at this moment all over the world.	12.720067841306989
All butting with their skulls to get out of it.	7.643925384848993
Child born every minute somewhere.	7.271881480328411
Mrs Purefoy.	9.884235987460922
He laid both books aside and glanced at the third: _Tales of the Ghetto_ by Leopold von Sacher Masoch.	11.162325812155188
—That I had, he said, pushing it by.	21.586932612336636
The shopman let two volumes fall on the counter.	7.301972063106755
—Them are two good ones, he said.	4.102790455118798
Onions of his breath came across the counter out of his ruined mouth.	18.921649872465935
He bent to make a bundle of the other books, hugged them against his unbuttoned waistcoat and bore them off behind the dingy curtain.	11.762953534809862
On O’Connell bridge many persons observed the grave deportment and gay apparel of Mr Denis J Maginni, professor of dancing &c.	6.0963220489131364
Mr Bloom, alone, looked at the titles.	28.22920773712593
_Fair Tyrants_ by James Lovebirch.	9.423032829323882
Know the kind that is.	7.661930846494952
Had it?	5.692550280399153
Yes.	9.732442163148734
He opened it.	4.481780497141782

Listen: the man.	20.266997784780592

Take this.	8.425917152462297

Mr Bloom read again: _The beautiful woman._ Warmth showered gently over him, cowing his flesh.	9.874951998205692

Mr Bloom beheld it.	10.64814717445105

Do others see me so?	9.864530780624644
Quick, far and daring.	12.112600047251115
Shadow of my mind.	15.015674959844658
He took the coverless book from her hand.	11.138756310734063
Chardenal’s French primer.	29.97825578467801
—What did you buy that for?	27.192220645169627
To learn French?	16.92538249648606
She nodded, reddening and closing tight her lips.	5.760077327578898
Show no surprise.	8.080465848484218
Quite natural.	13.943843522115227
—Here, Stephen said.	5.608572966227139
It’s all right.	5.592046872441169
Mind Maggy doesn’t pawn it on you.	8.706102468782085
I suppose all my books are gone.	10.162940354487667
—Some, Dilly said.	4.657890191971556
We had to.	16.40436299916229
She is drowning.	23.800675310486728
Agenbite.	25.50621404370786
Save her.	5.297514951622471
Agenbite.	25.50621404370786
All against us.	5.574429204789018
She will drown me with her, eyes and hair.	13.903232531947959
Lank coils of seaweed hair around me, my heart, my soul.	16.423828719000312
Salt green death.	6.0082205141070855
We. Agenbite of inwit.	7.1875908020176835
Inwit’s agenbite.	39.76832468340524
Misery! Misery! * * * —Hello, Simon, Father Cowley said.	4.1134960455652605
How are things?	10.846967812434627
—Hello, Bob, old man, Mr Dedalus answered, stopping.	27.97302186030783
They clasped hands loudly outside Reddy and Daughter’s.	4.323323539177745
Father Cowley brushed his moustache often downward with a scooping hand.	7.163254863641599
—What’s the best news?	9.483821459605483
Mr Dedalus said.	3.546703817366021
—Why then not much, Father Cowley said.	7.139349150099015
I’m barricaded up, Simon, with two men prowling around the house trying to effect an entrance.	20.734947882018954
—Jolly, Mr Dedalus said.	36.615983497409026
Who is it?	9.867507734124299
—O, Father Cowley said.	4.995687584095469
A certain gombeen man of our acquaintance.	16.077708674919702
—With a broken back, is it?	11.963698529867948
—The same, Simon, Father Cowley answered.	15.645949393369246
Reuben of that ilk.	21.300515748740285
I’m just waiting for Ben Dollard.	13.847156733226571
He’s going to say a word to long John to get him to take those two men off.	13.77959861480448
All I want is a little time.	19.03067138738738
He looked with vague hope up and down the quay, a big apple bulging in his neck.	15.486172309441914
—I know, Mr Dedalus said, nodding.	82.75772572313949
Poor old bockedy Ben! He’s always doing a good turn for someone.	14.481982796517265
Hold hard! He put on his glasses and gazed towards the metal bridge an instant.	18.657649383344246
—There he is, by God, he said, arse and pockets.	9.974974544690872
Ben Dollard’s loose blue cutaway and square hat above large slops crossed the quay in full gait from the metal bridge.	7.585877289009021
He came towards them at an amble, scratching actively behind his coattails.	10.636874100013658
—Hold him now, Ben Dollard said.	8.738156809545059
Mr Dedalus eyed with cold wandering scorn various points of Ben Dollard’s figure.	12.416033080113959
Then, turning to Father Cowley with a nod, he muttered sneeringly: —That’s a pretty garment, isn’t it, for a summer’s day?	24.116697430636723
—Why, God eternally curse your soul, Ben Dollard growled furiously, I threw out more clothes in my time than you ever saw.	12.043458580921998
He stood beside them beaming, on them first and on his roomy clothes from points of which Mr Dedalus flicked fluff, saying: —They were made for a man in his health, Ben, anyhow.	19.977122016114986
—Bad luck to the jewman that made them, Ben Dollard said.	12.287685872375238
Thanks be to God he’s not paid yet.	10.313655629017823
Father Cowley asked.	12.0300554305883
Cashel Boyle O’Connor Fitzmaurice Tisdall Farrell, murmuring, glassyeyed, strode past the Kildare street club.	5.692419906926981
Ben Dollard frowned and, making suddenly a chanter’s mouth, gave forth a deep note.	15.168965758680455
—Aw! he said.	3.0617397882484845
—That’s the style, Mr Dedalus said, nodding to its drone.	42.954598157009805
—What about that?	16.72464742208763
Ben Dollard said.	3.74650063900367
Not too dusty?	14.786396833216765
He turned to both.	16.652195523133344
—That’ll do, Father Cowley said, nodding also.	14.980097496239116
The reverend Hugh C.	5.122448899230054
Love walked from the old chapterhouse of saint Mary’s abbey past James and Charles Kennedy’s, rectifiers, attended by Geraldines tall and personable, towards the Tholsel beyond the ford of hurdles.	8.027726697404795

—Come along with me to the subsheriff’s office, he said.	11.852233945808623
I want to show you the new beauty Rock has for a bailiff.	21.26346800859322
He’s a cross between Lobengula and Lynchehaun.	9.446940861796035
He’s well worth seeing, mind you.	10.197670237836787
Come along.	24.81632615462123
I saw John Henry Menton casually in the Bodega just now and it will cost me a fall if I don’t...	13.100376703762137
Wait awhile...	4.801062254443455
We’re on the right lay, Bob, believe you me.	9.966264459619762
—For a few days tell him, Father Cowley said anxiously.	18.935308608772655
Ben Dollard halted and stared, his loud orifice open, a dangling button of his coat wagging brightbacked from its thread as he wiped away the heavy shraums that clogged his eyes to hear aright.	13.705533312487535
—What few days?	33.827785190485635
he boomed.	16.58211792698403
Hasn’t your landlord distrained for rent?	11.913523719300342

The landlord has the prior claim.	8.233815053337768
I gave him all the particulars.	18.83750911230275
29 Windsor avenue.	8.4492546945381
Love is the name?	21.905505231700584
The reverend Mr Love.	18.468674954037606
He’s a minister in the country somewhere.	17.47951967572848
But are you sure of that?	17.646539282086625

* * * —The youngster will be all right, Martin Cunningham said, as they passed out of the Castleyard gate.	14.364675124250454
The policeman touched his forehead.	8.281033538560886
Bronze by gold, Miss Kennedy’s head by Miss Douce’s head, appeared above the crossblind of the Ormond hotel.	11.554087224965503
—Yes, Martin Cunningham said, fingering his beard.	13.838619823340222
I wrote to Father Conmee and laid the whole case before him.	11.741032405664146

—Boyd?	16.58211792698403
Martin Cunningham said shortly.	15.592799087821135
Touch me not.	9.467906498216415

The castle car wheeled empty into upper Exchange street.	3.900983003196661

And put down the five shillings too.	13.5263260726441

John Wyse Nolan opened wide eyes.	7.22511188117461

—Righto, Martin Cunningham said.	3.3841729238840395
Here goes.	9.27938997935109
Outside _la Maison Claire_ Blazes Boylan waylaid Jack Mooney’s brother-in-law, humpy, tight, making for the liberties.	9.645411775961644
John Wyse Nolan fell back with Mr Power, while Martin Cunningham took the elbow of a dapper little man in a shower of hail suit, who walked uncertainly, with hasty steps past Micky Anderson’s watches.	15.930574508270311

They followed round the corner towards James Kavanagh’s winerooms.	14.894154150130895
The empty castle car fronted them at rest in Essex gate.	6.620227217740107
Martin Cunningham, speaking always, showed often the list at which Jimmy Henry did not glance.	9.798889467857453
—And long John Fanning is here too, John Wyse Nolan said, as large as life.	15.33280861267205
The tall form of long John Fanning filled the doorway where he stood.	13.919975332553138
—Good day, Mr Subsheriff, Martin Cunningham said, as all halted and greeted.	13.106534900955836
Long John Fanning made no way for them.	6.077426859689923
He removed his large Henry Clay decisively and his large fierce eyes scowled intelligently over all their faces.	9.638264927753111
—Are the conscript fathers pursuing their peaceful deliberations?	6.928581998228274
he said with rich acrid utterance to the assistant town clerk.	12.119477888020302
Where was the marshal, he wanted to know, to keep order in the council chamber.	28.79271164419158
And old Barlow the macebearer laid up with asthma, no mace on the table, nothing in order, no quorum even, and Hutchinson, the lord mayor, in Llandudno and little Lorcan Sherlock doing _locum tenens_ for him.	12.312827750470964
Damned Irish language, language of our forefathers.	13.701816151614432
Long John Fanning blew a plume of smoke from his lips.	8.82161830958454
Martin Cunningham spoke by turns, twirling the peak of his beard, to the assistant town clerk and the subsheriff, while John Wyse Nolan held his peace.	11.400980862504925
—What Dignam was that?	12.195572671266508
long John Fanning asked.	8.212018741630938
Jimmy Henry made a grimace and lifted his left foot.	22.041875146648017
—O, my corns! he said plaintively.	19.1132113863367
Come upstairs for goodness’ sake till I sit down somewhere.	8.857238150310755
Uff! Ooo! Mind! Testily he made room for himself beside long John Fanning’s flank and passed in and up the stairs.	11.857423378715229
—Come on up, Martin Cunningham said to the subsheriff.	22.47679979623963
I don’t think you knew him or perhaps you did, though.	13.500779786841983
With John Wyse Nolan Mr Power followed them in.	10.94518674274975
—Decent little soul he was, Mr Power said to the stalwart back of long John Fanning ascending towards long John Fanning in the mirror.	11.085697334609343
—Rather lowsized.	14.786396833216765
Dignam of Menton’s office that was, Martin Cunningham said.	8.14849620633186
Long John Fanning could not remember him.	7.760521240195551
Clatter of horsehoofs sounded from the air.	6.13932890329361
—What’s that?	9.356975705049678
All turned where they stood.	12.097282916833851
John Wyse Nolan came down again.	8.596324596236576

In saddles of the leaders, leaping leaders, rode outriders.	17.13396730440217

Martin Cunningham asked, as they went on up the staircase.	19.635468214695173

* * * As they trod across the thick carpet Buck Mulligan whispered behind his Panama to Haines: —Parnell’s brother.	11.944401205198243
There in the corner.	14.402757203372815
They chose a small table near the window, opposite a longfaced man whose beard and gaze hung intently down on a chessboard.	6.915894593130107
—Is that he?	29.199011576170147
Haines asked, twisting round in his seat.	20.98649616997823
—Yes, Mulligan said.	7.292957572935416
That’s John Howard, his brother, our city marshal.	32.57444832529749
John Howard Parnell translated a white bishop quietly and his grey claw went up again to his forehead whereat it rested.	11.066571052920185
An instant after, under its screen, his eyes looked quickly, ghostbright, at his foe and fell once more upon a working corner.	12.739707999785715
—I’ll take a _mélange,_ Haines said to the waitress.	15.693931562577761
—Two _mélanges,_ Buck Mulligan said.	5.334992436632982
When she had gone he said, laughing: —We call it D.B.C. because they have damn bad cakes.	24.204721913430472
O, but you missed Dedalus on _Hamlet._ Haines opened his newbought book.	9.165564489217203
—I’m sorry, he said.	5.453458150450613
Shakespeare is the happy huntingground of all minds that have lost their balance.	13.75699789099207
The onelegged sailor growled at the area of 14 Nelson street: —_England expects_...	11.801098114583283
Buck Mulligan’s primrose waistcoat shook gaily to his laughter.	15.136253973458178
—You should see him, he said, when his body loses its balance.	16.392882500489254
Wandering Ængus I call him.	4.461056331080397
—I am sure he has an _idée fixe,_ Haines said, pinching his chin thoughtfully with thumb and forefinger.	11.210013305231834
Now I am speculating what it would be likely to be.	17.483906077511335
Such persons always have.	4.71554917311125
Buck Mulligan bent across the table gravely.	25.390290627161807
—They drove his wits astray, he said, by visions of hell.	16.17831235199498
He will never capture the Attic note.	7.591171246084201
The note of Swinburne, of all poets, the white death and the ruddy birth.	12.774474941690904
That is his tragedy.	24.463185250082724
He can never be a poet.	17.987777635586536
The joy of creation...	5.29882648359082
—Eternal punishment, Haines said, nodding curtly.	8.142597199324005
I see.	8.216557747377024
I tackled him this morning on belief.	9.328596031747926
There was something on his mind, I saw.	29.371012650633187
It’s rather interesting because professor Pokorny of Vienna makes an interesting point out of that.	7.1745871697055845
Buck Mulligan’s watchful eyes saw the waitress come.	12.946085649927339
He helped her to unload her tray.	8.30913248243208
—He can find no trace of hell in ancient Irish myth, Haines said, amid the cheerful cups.	10.615347375363198
The moral idea seems lacking, the sense of destiny, of retribution.	11.671534731411812
Rather strange he should have just that fixed idea.	10.503614213191943
Does he write anything for your movement?	13.737250603870313
He sank two lumps of sugar deftly longwise through the whipped cream.	8.65514031567363
Buck Mulligan slit a steaming scone in two and plastered butter over its smoking pith.	8.05233322971591
He bit off a soft piece hungrily.	16.574386962267802
—Ten years, he said, chewing and laughing.	12.779005142282571
He is going to write something in ten years.	10.14055013032267
—Seems a long way off, Haines said, thoughtfully lifting his spoon.	11.823895390132998
Still, I shouldn’t wonder if he did after all.	14.742858482847545
He tasted a spoonful from the creamy cone of his cup.	13.968916155786692
—This is real Irish cream I take it, he said with forbearance.	11.985498542338057
I don’t want to be imposed on.	9.870498789686469
Elijah, skiff, light crumpled throwaway, sailed eastward by flanks of ships and trawlers, amid an archipelago of corks, beyond new Wapping street past Benson’s ferry, and by the threemasted schooner _Rosevean_ from Bridgwater with bricks.	6.390068165613646
* * * Almidano Artifoni walked past Holles street, past Sewell’s yard.	12.304099072622396
Behind him Cashel Boyle O’Connor Fitzmaurice Tisdall Farrell, with stickumbrelladustcoat dangling, shunned the lamp before Mr Law Smith’s house and, crossing, walked along Merrion square.	10.36550600080673
Distantly behind him a blind stripling tapped his way by the wall of College park.	15.421929837375208
Cashel Boyle O’Connor Fitzmaurice Tisdall Farrell walked as far as Mr Lewis Werner’s cheerful windows, then turned and strode back along Merrion square, his stickumbrelladustcoat dangling.	9.384382972817058
At the corner of Wilde’s house he halted, frowned at Elijah’s name announced on the Metropolitan hall, frowned at the distant pleasance of duke’s lawn.	17.69970131286874
His eyeglass flashed frowning in the sun.	6.901316090734159
With ratsteeth bared he muttered: —_Coactus volui._ He strode on for Clare street, grinding his fierce word.	9.660464599969279
As he strode past Mr Bloom’s dental windows the sway of his dustcoat brushed rudely from its angle a slender tapping cane and swept onwards, having buffeted a thewless body.	8.048003815258557
The blind stripling turned his sickly face after the striding form.	9.25813598899513
—God’s curse on you, he said sourly, whoever you are! You’re blinder nor I am, you bitch’s bastard! * * * Opposite Ruggy O’Donohoe’s Master Patrick Aloysius Dignam, pawing the pound and a half of Mangan’s, late Fehrenbach’s, porksteaks he had been sent for, went along warm Wicklow street dawdling.	11.000817848370897
It was too blooming dull sitting in the parlour with Mrs Stoer and Mrs Quigley and Mrs MacDowell and the blind down and they all at their sniffles and sipping sups of the superior tawny sherry uncle Barney brought from Tunney’s.	12.613795446334137
And they eating crumbs of the cottage fruitcake, jawing the whole blooming time and sighing.	11.09679330512353
After Wicklow lane the window of Madame Doyle, courtdress milliner, stopped him.	5.69270949642109
He stood looking in at the two puckers stripped to their pelts and putting up their props.	17.00311439643613
From the sidemirrors two mourning Masters Dignam gaped silently.	6.567203418458958
Myler Keogh, Dublin’s pet lamb, will meet sergeantmajor Bennett, the Portobello bruiser, for a purse of fifty sovereigns.	11.128759453828268
Gob, that’d be a good pucking match to see.	14.014348304295842
Myler Keogh, that’s the chap sparring out to him with the green sash.	9.16603079343834
Two bar entrance, soldiers half price.	5.688397190020534
I could easy do a bunk on ma.	12.9898703905174
Master Dignam on his left turned as he turned.	23.29446650769882
That’s me in mourning.	26.940233700152362
When is it?	6.148420547898318
May the twentysecond.	16.92538249648606
Sure, the blooming thing is all over.	21.310727663717287
He turned to the right and on his right Master Dignam turned, his cap awry, his collar sticking up.	20.386525402508187
Buttoning it down, his chin lifted, he saw the image of Marie Kendall, charming soubrette, beside the two puckers.	17.155289799260924
One of them mots that do be in the packets of fags Stoer smokes that his old fellow welted hell out of him for one time he found out.	11.205187756110535
The best pucker going for strength was Fitzsimons.	10.09296801162919
One puck in the wind from that fellow would knock you into the middle of next week, man.	12.136376203720713
But the best pucker for science was Jem Corbet before Fitzsimons knocked the stuffings out of him, dodging and all.	7.428927539492126
In Grafton street Master Dignam saw a red flower in a toff’s mouth and a swell pair of kicks on him and he listening to what the drunk was telling him and grinning all the time.	20.701227230478384
No Sandymount tram.	7.554588130286805
Master Dignam walked along Nassau street, shifted the porksteaks to his other hand.	10.562035634111563
His collar sprang up again and he tugged it down.	10.341111652508078
The blooming stud was too small for the buttonhole of the shirt, blooming end to it.	10.231529520547214
He met schoolboys with satchels.	8.665330132049261
I’m not going tomorrow either, stay away till Monday.	8.868221491057533
He met other schoolboys.	9.645223575437983
Do they notice I’m in mourning?	14.189857303402373
Uncle Barney said he’d get it into the paper tonight.	13.423945416841306
Then they’ll all see it in the paper and read my name printed and pa’s name.	15.448225754202472
His face got all grey instead of being red like it was and there was a fly walking over it up to his eye.	16.132135307553895
The scrunch that was when they were screwing the screws into the coffin: and the bumps when they were bringing it downstairs.	15.5531704396791
Pa was inside it and ma crying in the parlour and uncle Barney telling the men how to get it round the bend.	15.210702206370682
A big coffin it was, and high and heavylooking.	16.497007141820475
How was that?	10.56532800913548
The last night pa was boosed he was standing on the landing there bawling out for his boots to go out to Tunney’s for to boose more and he looked butty and short in his shirt.	16.54553373731805
Never see him again.	11.844055132395809
Death, that is.	6.701357311337003
Pa is dead.	5.661570617977777
My father is dead.	8.716246069344892
He told me to be a good son to ma.	20.63055837189174
I couldn’t hear the other things he said but I saw his tongue and his teeth trying to say it better.	30.4295817993957
Poor pa.	12.599684944605478
That was Mr Dignam, my father.	27.064106030895204
I hope he’s in purgatory now because he went to confession to Father Conroy on Saturday night.	11.921607328038434
* * * William Humble, earl of Dudley, and lady Dudley, accompanied by lieutenantcolonel Heseltine, drove out after luncheon from the viceregal lodge.	8.715830882796837
In the following carriage were the honourable Mrs Paget, Miss de Courcy and the honourable Gerald Ward A.	9.644599376724852
D.	10.582866589593744
in attendance.	15.973570383039265
The cavalcade passed out by the lower gate of Phoenix park saluted by obsequious policemen and proceeded past Kingsbridge along the northern quays.	10.004530515409437
The viceroy was most cordially greeted on his way through the metropolis.	15.003731686868498
At Bloody bridge Mr Thomas Kernan beyond the river greeted him vainly from afar.	7.16924236943298
Between Queen’s and Whitworth bridges lord Dudley’s viceregal carriages passed and were unsaluted by Mr Dudley White, B.	7.68310070848728
L., M.	8.813675896779905
A., who stood on Arran quay outside Mrs M.	13.116069994855225
E.	10.582866589593744
White’s, the pawnbroker’s, at the corner of Arran street west stroking his nose with his forefinger, undecided whether he should arrive at Phibsborough more quickly by a triple change of tram or by hailing a car or on foot through Smithfield, Constitution hill and Broadstone terminus.	11.535745514208172
In the porch of Four Courts Richie Goulding with the costbag of Goulding, Collis and Ward saw him with surprise.	11.217554002630242
Past Richmond bridge at the doorstep of the office of Reuben J Dodd, solicitor, agent for the Patriotic Insurance Company, an elderly female about to enter changed her plan and retracing her steps by King’s windows smiled credulously on the representative of His Majesty.	10.257942344946269
From its sluice in Wood quay wall under Tom Devan’s office Poddle river hung out in fealty a tongue of liquid sewage.	6.296308726638019
Above the crossblind of the Ormond hotel, gold by bronze, Miss Kennedy’s head by Miss Douce’s head watched and admired.	10.797702105680365
On Ormond quay Mr Simon Dedalus, steering his way from the greenhouse for the subsheriff’s office, stood still in midstreet and brought his hat low.	14.611749124929789
His Excellency graciously returned Mr Dedalus’ greeting.	15.136458122369302
From Cahill’s corner the reverend Hugh C.	10.738616201622136
A., made obeisance unperceived, mindful of lords deputies whose hands benignant had held of yore rich advowsons.	6.019243030555324
On Grattan bridge Lenehan and M’Coy, taking leave of each other, watched the carriages go by.	9.05552491411713

There’s a bloody big foxy thief beyond by the garrison church at the corner of Chicken lane—old Troy was just giving me a wrinkle about him—lifted any God’s quantity of tea and sugar to pay three bob a week said he had a farm in the county Down off a hop-of-my-thumb by the name of Moses Herzog over there near Heytesbury street.	10.217969400663494
—Circumcised?	16.58211792698403

A bit off the top.	35.6518181952541
An old plumber named Geraghty.	10.727138689141

—That the lay you’re on now?	15.190023751303382
—Ay, says I.	6.570652367110804
How are the mighty fallen! Collector of bad and doubtful debts.	7.25736116556106

Geraghty, esquire, of 29 Arbour hill in the city of Dublin, Arran quay ward, gentleman, hereinafter called the purchaser, videlicet, five pounds avoirdupois of first choice tea at three shillings and no pence per pound avoirdupois and three stone avoirdupois of sugar, crushed crystal, at threepence per pound avoirdupois, the said purchaser debtor to the said vendor of one pound five shillings and sixpence sterling for value received which amount shall be paid by said purchaser to said vendor in weekly instalments every seven calendar days of three shillings and no pence sterling: and the said nonperishable goods shall not be pawned or pledged or sold or otherwise alienated by the said purchaser but shall be and remain and be held to be the sole and exclusive property of the said vendor to be disposed of at his good will and pleasure until the said amount shall have been duly paid by the said purchaser to the said vendor in the manner herein set forth as this day hereby agreed between the said vendor, his heirs, successors, trustees and assigns of the one part and the said purchaser, his heirs, successors, trustees and assigns of the other part.	9.251678123392338

In Inisfail the fair there lies a land, the land of holy Michan.	11.168581612507865
There rises a watchtower beheld of men afar.	7.630665624492241
There sleep the mighty dead as in life they slept, warriors and princes of high renown.	8.016973023707815
A pleasant land it is in sooth of murmuring waters, fishful streams where sport the gurnard, the plaice, the roach, the halibut, the gibbed haddock, the grilse, the dab, the brill, the flounder, the pollock, the mixed coarse fish generally and other denizens of the aqueous kingdom too numerous to be enumerated.	15.684291984948597
In the mild breezes of the west and of the east the lofty trees wave in different directions their firstclass foliage, the wafty sycamore, the Lebanonian cedar, the exalted planetree, the eugenic eucalyptus and other ornaments of the arboreal world with which that region is thoroughly well supplied.	14.599429311094474
Lovely maidens sit in close proximity to the roots of the lovely trees singing the most lovely songs while they play with all kinds of lovely objects as for example golden ingots, silvery fishes, crans of herrings, drafts of eels, codlings, creels of fingerlings, purple seagems and playful insects.	7.18504656193379
And heroes voyage from afar to woo them, from Eblana to Slievemargy, the peerless princes of unfettered Munster and of Connacht the just and of smooth sleek Leinster and of Cruachan’s land and of Armagh the splendid and of the noble district of Boyle, princes, the sons of kings.	11.580292549930528
And there rises a shining palace whose crystal glittering roof is seen by mariners who traverse the extensive sea in barks built expressly for that purpose, and thither come all herds and fatlings and firstfruits of that land for O’Connell Fitzsimon takes toll of them, a chieftain descended from chieftains.	7.308818474059236
Thither the extremely large wains bring foison of the fields, flaskets of cauliflowers, floats of spinach, pineapple chunks, Rangoon beans, strikes of tomatoes, drums of figs, drills of Swedes, spherical potatoes and tallies of iridescent kale, York and Savoy, and trays of onions, pearls of the earth, and punnets of mushrooms and custard marrows and fat vetches and bere and rape and red green yellow brown russet sweet big bitter ripe pomellated apples and chips of strawberries and sieves of gooseberries, pulpy and pelurious, and strawberries fit for princes and raspberries from their canes.	4.464504498741892

The figure seated on a large boulder at the foot of a round tower was that of a broadshouldered deepchested stronglimbed frankeyed redhaired freelyfreckled shaggybearded widemouthed largenosed longheaded deepvoiced barekneed brawnyhanded hairylegged ruddyfaced sinewyarmed hero.	7.218791622466704
From shoulder to shoulder he measured several ells and his rocklike mountainous knees were covered, as was likewise the rest of his body wherever visible, with a strong growth of tawny prickly hair in hue and toughness similar to the mountain gorse (_Ulex Europeus_).	7.70258013039002
The widewinged nostrils, from which bristles of the same tawny hue projected, were of such capaciousness that within their cavernous obscurity the fieldlark might easily have lodged her nest.	8.321236701779055
The eyes in which a tear and a smile strove ever for the mastery were of the dimensions of a goodsized cauliflower.	26.12462269058898
A powerful current of warm breath issued at regular intervals from the profound cavity of his mouth while in rhythmic resonance the loud strong hale reverberations of his formidable heart thundered rumblingly causing the ground, the summit of the lofty tower and the still loftier walls of the cave to vibrate and tremble.	10.358313035375996
He wore a long unsleeved garment of recently flayed oxhide reaching to the knees in a loose kilt and this was bound about his middle by a girdle of plaited straw and rushes.	9.400440298542835
Beneath this he wore trews of deerskin, roughly stitched with gut.	5.7223945472362505

In the darkness spirit hands were felt to flutter and when prayer by tantras had been directed to the proper quarter a faint but increasing luminosity of ruby light became gradually visible, the apparition of the etheric double being particularly lifelike owing to the discharge of jivic rays from the crown of the head and face.	10.45975966155032
Communication was effected through the pituitary body and also by means of the orangefiery and scarlet rays emanating from the sacral region and solar plexus.	9.393672742035585
Questioned by his earthname as to his whereabouts in the heavenworld he stated that he was now on the path of prālāyā or return but was still submitted to trial at the hands of certain bloodthirsty entities on the lower astral levels.	12.538717008326257
In reply to a question as to his first sensations in the great divide beyond he stated that previously he had seen as in a glass darkly but that those who had passed over had summit possibilities of atmic development opened up to them.	15.7569994256587
Interrogated as to whether life there resembled our experience in the flesh he stated that he had heard from more favoured beings now in the spirit that their abodes were equipped with every modern home comfort such as tālāfānā, ālāvātār, hātākāldā, wātāklāsāt and that the highest adepts were steeped in waves of volupcy of the very purest nature.	7.612443318291023

Time they were stopping up in the _City Arms_ pisser Burke told me there was an old one there with a cracked loodheramaun of a nephew and Bloom trying to get the soft side of her doing the mollycoddle playing bézique to come in for a bit of the wampum in her will and not eating meat of a Friday because the old one was always thumping her craw and taking the lout out for a walk.	17.764789552457923
And one time he led him the rounds of Dublin and, by the holy farmer, he never cried crack till he brought him home as drunk as a boiled owl and he said he did it to teach him the evils of alcohol and by herrings, if the three women didn’t near roast him, it’s a queer story, the old one, Bloom’s wife and Mrs O’Dowd that kept the hotel.	20.20014753250434

From the belfries far and near the funereal deathbell tolled unceasingly while all around the gloomy precincts rolled the ominous warning of a hundred muffled drums punctuated by the hollow booming of pieces of ordnance.	10.801261910249915
The deafening claps of thunder and the dazzling flashes of lightning which lit up the ghastly scene testified that the artillery of heaven had lent its supernatural pomp to the already gruesome spectacle.	6.5331924564210615
A torrential rain poured down from the floodgates of the angry heavens upon the bared heads of the assembled multitude which numbered at the lowest computation five hundred thousand persons.	11.295697649897606
A posse of Dublin Metropolitan police superintended by the Chief Commissioner in person maintained order in the vast throng for whom the York street brass and reed band whiled away the intervening time by admirably rendering on their blackdraped instruments the matchless melody endeared to us from the cradle by Speranza’s plaintive muse.	8.494718338185036
Special quick excursion trains and upholstered charabancs had been provided for the comfort of our country cousins of whom there were large contingents.	8.462096945177402
Considerable amusement was caused by the favourite Dublin streetsingers L-n-h-n and M-ll-g-n who sang _The Night before Larry was stretched_ in their usual mirth-provoking fashion.	5.412647380689523
Our two inimitable drolls did a roaring trade with their broadsheets among lovers of the comedy element and nobody who has a corner in his heart for real Irish fun without vulgarity will grudge them their hardearned pennies.	8.609072464577975
The viceregal houseparty which included many wellknown ladies was chaperoned by Their Excellencies to the most favourable positions on the grandstand while the picturesque foreign delegation known as the Friends of the Emerald Isle was accommodated on a tribune directly opposite.	8.47337513414958
The delegation, present in full force, consisted of Commendatore Bacibaci Beninobenone (the semiparalysed _doyen_ of the party who had to be assisted to his seat by the aid of a powerful steam crane), Monsieur Pierrepaul Petitépatant, the Grandjoker Vladinmire Pokethankertscheff, the Archjoker Leopold Rudolph von Schwanzenbad-Hodenthaler, Countess Marha Virága Kisászony Putrápesthi, Hiram Y.	8.860977487448658

All the delegates without exception expressed themselves in the strongest possible heterogeneous terms concerning the nameless barbarity which they had been called upon to witness.	9.6255644537939
An animated altercation (in which all took part) ensued among the F.	7.031073114972666
E.	10.582866589593744
as to whether the eighth or the ninth of March was the correct date of the birth of Ireland’s patron saint.	13.916860461114686
In the course of the argument cannonballs, scimitars, boomerangs, blunderbusses, stinkpots, meatchoppers, umbrellas, catapults, knuckledusters, sandbags, lumps of pig iron were resorted to and blows were freely exchanged.	5.361917001743268
The baby policeman, Constable MacFadden, summoned by special courier from Booterstown, quickly restored order and with lightning promptitude proposed the seventeenth of the month as a solution equally honourable for both contending parties.	5.2822277359912
The readywitted ninefooter’s suggestion at once appealed to all and was unanimously accepted.	16.142577059085657
Constable MacFadden was heartily congratulated by all the F.	7.693983900860409
E.	10.582866589593744
I., several of whom were bleeding profusely.	17.21054678720651
Commendatore Beninobenone having been extricated from underneath the presidential armchair, it was explained by his legal adviser Avvocato Pagamimi that the various articles secreted in his thirtytwo pockets had been abstracted by him during the affray from the pockets of his junior colleagues in the hope of bringing them to their senses.	12.305656790670154
The objects (which included several hundred ladies’ and gentlemen’s gold and silver watches) were promptly restored to their rightful owners and general harmony reigned supreme.	9.144401403485059
Quietly, unassumingly Rumbold stepped on to the scaffold in faultless morning dress and wearing his favourite flower, the _Gladiolus Cruentus_.	9.585298883701025
He announced his presence by that gentle Rumboldian cough which so many have tried (unsuccessfully) to imitate—short, painstaking yet withal so characteristic of the man.	6.858247678946136
The arrival of the worldrenowned headsman was greeted by a roar of acclamation from the huge concourse, the viceregal ladies waving their handkerchiefs in their excitement while the even more excitable foreign delegates cheered vociferously in a medley of cries, _hoch, banzai, eljen, zivio, chinchin, polla kronia, hiphip, vive, Allah_, amid which the ringing _evviva_ of the delegate of the land of song (a high double F recalling those piercingly lovely notes with which the eunuch Catalani beglamoured our greatgreatgrandmothers) was easily distinguishable.	7.163115834921842
It was exactly seventeen o’clock.	9.686199635978566
The signal for prayer was then promptly given by megaphone and in an instant all heads were bared, the commendatore’s patriarchal sombrero, which has been in the possession of his family since the revolution of Rienzi, being removed by his medical adviser in attendance, Dr Pippi.	13.302106748947255
The learned prelate who administered the last comforts of holy religion to the hero martyr when about to pay the death penalty knelt in a most christian spirit in a pool of rainwater, his cassock above his hoary head, and offered up to the throne of grace fervent prayers of supplication.	11.33384232290607
As he awaited the fatal signal he tested the edge of his horrible weapon by honing it upon his brawny forearm or decapitated in rapid succession a flock of sheep which had been provided by the admirers of his fell but necessary office.	6.204555179038691
On a handsome mahogany table near him were neatly arranged the quartering knife, the various finely tempered disembowelling appliances (specially supplied by the worldfamous firm of cutlers, Messrs John Round and Sons, Sheffield), a terra cotta saucepan for the reception of the duodenum, colon, blind intestine and appendix etc when successfully extracted and two commodious milkjugs destined to receive the most precious blood of the most precious victim.	7.953553085029644
The housesteward of the amalgamated cats’ and dogs’ home was in attendance to convey these vessels when replenished to that beneficent institution.	8.563289470162237
Quite an excellent repast consisting of rashers and eggs, fried steak and onions, done to a nicety, delicious hot breakfast rolls and invigorating tea had been considerately provided by the authorities for the consumption of the central figure of the tragedy who was in capital spirits when prepared for death and evinced the keenest interest in the proceedings from beginning to end but he, with an abnegation rare in these our times, rose nobly to the occasion and expressed the dying wish (immediately acceded to) that the meal should be divided in aliquot parts among the members of the sick and indigent roomkeepers’ association as a token of his regard and esteem.	10.232682036145775
The _nec_ and _non plus ultra_ of emotion were reached when the blushing bride elect burst her way through the serried ranks of the bystanders and flung herself upon the muscular bosom of him who was about to be launched into eternity for her sake.	10.485480842736491
The hero folded her willowy form in a loving embrace murmuring fondly _Sheila, my own_.	8.102368195816549
Encouraged by this use of her christian name she kissed passionately all the various suitable areas of his person which the decencies of prison garb permitted her ardour to reach.	10.82266064281848
She swore to him as they mingled the salt streams of their tears that she would ever cherish his memory, that she would never forget her hero boy who went to his death with a song on his lips as if he were but going to a hurling match in Clonturk park.	11.668421840230753
She brought back to his recollection the happy days of blissful childhood together on the banks of Anna Liffey when they had indulged in the innocent pastimes of the young and, oblivious of the dreadful present, they both laughed heartily, all the spectators, including the venerable pastor, joining in the general merriment.	15.570749657676478
That monster audience simply rocked with delight.	4.154716111572848
But anon they were overcome with grief and clasped their hands for the last time.	8.519768903342655
A fresh torrent of tears burst from their lachrymal ducts and the vast concourse of people, touched to the inmost core, broke into heartrending sobs, not the least affected being the aged prebendary himself.	9.30278873223865
Big strong men, officers of the peace and genial giants of the royal Irish constabulary, were making frank use of their handkerchiefs and it is safe to say that there was not a dry eye in that record assemblage.	16.18061109088588
A most romantic incident occurred when a handsome young Oxford graduate, noted for his chivalry towards the fair sex, stepped forward and, presenting his visiting card, bankbook and genealogical tree, solicited the hand of the hapless young lady, requesting her to name the day, and was accepted on the spot.	10.411165828013852
Every lady in the audience was presented with a tasteful souvenir of the occasion in the shape of a skull and crossbones brooch, a timely and generous act which evoked a fresh outburst of emotion: and when the gallant young Oxonian (the bearer, by the way, of one of the most timehonoured names in Albion’s history) placed on the finger of his blushing _fiancée_ an expensive engagement ring with emeralds set in the form of a fourleaved shamrock the excitement knew no bounds.	11.541419893656917
Nay, even the stern provostmarshal, lieutenantcolonel Tomkin-Maxwell ffrenchmullan Tomlinson, who presided on the sad occasion, he who had blown a considerable number of sepoys from the cannonmouth without flinching, could not now restrain his natural emotion.	11.081011820047989
With his mailed gauntlet he brushed away a furtive tear and was overheard, by those privileged burghers who happened to be in his immediate _entourage,_ to murmur to himself in a faltering undertone: —God blimey if she aint a clinker, that there bleeding tart.	12.061758513123877
Blimey it makes me kind of bleeding cry, straight, it does, when I sees her cause I thinks of my old mashtub what’s waiting for me down Limehouse way.	13.099450785394714
So then the citizen begins talking about the Irish language and the corporation meeting and all to that and the shoneens that can’t speak their own language and Joe chipping in because he stuck someone for a quid and Bloom putting in his old goo with his twopenny stump that he cadged off of Joe and talking about the Gaelic league and the antitreating league and drink, the curse of Ireland.	17.272585417082162
Antitreating is about the size of it.	8.541915790651386
Gob, he’d let you pour all manner of drink down his throat till the Lord would call him before you’d ever see the froth of his pint.	18.27817233218106
And one night I went in with a fellow into one of their musical evenings, song and dance about she could get up on a truss of hay she could my Maureen Lay and there was a fellow with a Ballyhooly blue ribbon badge spiffing out of him in Irish and a lot of colleen bawns going about with temperance beverages and selling medals and oranges and lemonade and a few old dry buns, gob, flahoolagh entertainment, don’t be talking.	10.373160333547014
Ireland sober is Ireland free.	5.483102864076354
And then an old fellow starts blowing into his bagpipes and all the gougers shuffling their feet to the tune the old cow died of.	13.670083559371397
And one or two sky pilots having an eye around that there was no goings on with the females, hitting below the belt.	8.376036445720594
So howandever, as I was saying, the old dog seeing the tin was empty starts mousing around by Joe and me.	11.549223292112908
I’d train him by kindness, so I would, if he was my dog.	17.565219579111698
Give him a rousing fine kick now and again where it wouldn’t blind him.	8.230419859857282
—Afraid he’ll bite you?	9.112267498972614
says the citizen, jeering.	11.678846983063726
—No, says I.	8.545489960745524
But he might take my leg for a lamppost.	32.61803938459059
So he calls the old dog over.	15.966525920341997
—What’s on you, Garry?	19.084830175989772
says he.	6.2246949987246945
Then he starts hauling and mauling and talking to him in Irish and the old towser growling, letting on to answer, like a duet in the opera.	11.072610333482062
Such growling you never heard as they let off between them.	9.289935533124275
Growling and grousing and his eye all bloodshot from the drouth is in it and the hydrophobia dropping out of his jaws.	21.289545270738774
All those who are interested in the spread of human culture among the lower animals (and their name is legion) should make a point of not missing the really marvellous exhibition of cynanthropy given by the famous old Irish red setter wolfdog formerly known by the _sobriquet_ of Garryowen and recently rechristened by his large circle of friends and acquaintances Owen Garry.	9.679401552632116
The exhibition, which is the result of years of training by kindness and a carefully thoughtout dietary system, comprises, among other achievements, the recitation of verse.	10.453553662582564
Our greatest living phonetic expert (wild horses shall not drag it from us!) has left no stone unturned in his efforts to delucidate and compare the verse recited and has found it bears a _striking_ resemblance (the italics are ours) to the ranns of ancient Celtic bards.	6.837009060081198
We are not speaking so much of those delightful lovesongs with which the writer who conceals his identity under the graceful pseudonym of the Little Sweet Branch has familiarised the bookloving world but rather (as a contributor D.	9.67608772605832
points out in an interesting communication published by an evening contemporary) of the harsher and more personal note which is found in the satirical effusions of the famous Raftery and of Donal MacConsidine to say nothing of a more modern lyrist at present very much in the public eye.	13.193783066219815
We subjoin a specimen which has been rendered into English by an eminent scholar whose name for the moment we are not at liberty to disclose though we believe that our readers will find the topical allusion rather more than an indication.	7.775420167678635
The metrical system of the canine original, which recalls the intricate alliterative and isosyllabic rules of the Welsh englyn, is infinitely more complicated but we believe our readers will agree that the spirit has been well caught.	9.502227951516153
Perhaps it should be added that the effect is greatly increased if Owen’s verse be spoken somewhat slowly and indistinctly in a tone suggestive of suppressed rancour.	8.58847148342178
The curse of my curses Seven days every day And seven dry Thursdays On you, Barney Kiernan, Has no sup of water To cool my courage, And my guts red roaring After Lowry’s lights.	7.286623649014902

A most interesting discussion took place in the ancient hall of _Brian O’Ciarnain’s_ in _Sraid na Bretaine Bheag_, under the auspices of _Sluagh na h-Eireann_, on the revival of ancient Gaelic sports and the importance of physical culture, as understood in ancient Greece and ancient Rome and ancient Ireland, for the development of the race.	9.130370791159457
The venerable president of the noble order was in the chair and the attendance was of large dimensions.	16.496561172376122
After an instructive discourse by the chairman, a magnificent oration eloquently and forcibly expressed, a most interesting and instructive discussion of the usual high standard of excellence ensued as to the desirability of the revivability of the ancient games and sports of our ancient Panceltic forefathers.	12.90672736722296
The wellknown and highly respected worker in the cause of our old tongue, Mr Joseph M’Carthy Hynes, made an eloquent appeal for the resuscitation of the ancient Gaelic sports and pastimes, practised morning and evening by Finn MacCool, as calculated to revive the best traditions of manly strength and prowess handed down to us from ancient ages.	9.364602716222079
L.	10.990294469428525
Bloom, who met with a mixed reception of applause and hisses, having espoused the negative the vocalist chairman brought the discussion to a close, in response to repeated requests and hearty plaudits from all parts of a bumper house, by a remarkably noteworthy rendering of the immortal Thomas Osborne Davis’ evergreen verses (happily too familiar to need recalling here) _A nation once again_ in the execution of which the veteran patriot champion may be said without fear of contradiction to have fairly excelled himself.	8.819915987977357
The Irish Caruso-Garibaldi was in superlative form and his stentorian notes were heard to the greatest advantage in the timehonoured anthem sung as only our citizen can sing it.	9.242701688098656
His superb highclass vocalism, which by its superquality greatly enhanced his already international reputation, was vociferously applauded by the large audience among which were to be noticed many prominent members of the clergy as well as representatives of the press and the bar and the other learned professions.	11.49241424824182

And whereas on the sixteenth day of the month of the oxeyed goddess and in the third week after the feastday of the Holy and Undivided Trinity, the daughter of the skies, the virgin moon being then in her first quarter, it came to pass that those learned judges repaired them to the halls of law.	19.732806387240508
There master Courtenay, sitting in his own chamber, gave his rede and master Justice Andrews, sitting without a jury in the probate court, weighed well and pondered the claim of the first chargeant upon the property in the matter of the will propounded and final testamentary disposition _in re_ the real and personal estate of the late lamented Jacob Halliday, vintner, deceased, versus Livingstone, an infant, of unsound mind, and another.	10.794641448092822

And there sat with him the high sinhedrim of the twelve tribes of Iar, for every tribe one man, of the tribe of Patrick and of the tribe of Hugh and of the tribe of Owen and of the tribe of Conn and of the tribe of Oscar and of the tribe of Fergus and of the tribe of Finn and of the tribe of Dermot and of the tribe of Cormac and of the tribe of Kevin and of the tribe of Caolte and of the tribe of Ossian, there being in all twelve good men and true.	10.581950685633144
And he conjured them by Him who died on rood that they should well and truly try and true deliverance make in the issue joined between their sovereign lord the king and the prisoner at the bar and true verdict give according to the evidence so help them God and kiss the book.	11.591849427897115

And our potteries and textiles, the finest in the whole world! And our wool that was sold in Rome in the time of Juvenal and our flax and our damask from the looms of Antrim and our Limerick lace, our tanneries and our white flint glass down there by Ballybough and our Huguenot poplin that we have since Jacquard de Lyon and our woven silk and our Foxford tweeds and ivory raised point from the Carmelite convent in New Ross, nothing like it in the whole wide world.	9.723523623122755

The bride who was given away by her father, the M’Conifer of the Glands, looked exquisitely charming in a creation carried out in green mercerised silk, moulded on an underslip of gloaming grey, sashed with a yoke of broad emerald and finished with a triple flounce of darkerhued fringe, the scheme being relieved by bretelles and hip insertions of acorn bronze.	9.822802535994127
The maids of honour, Miss Larch Conifer and Miss Spruce Conifer, sisters of the bride, wore very becoming costumes in the same tone, a dainty _motif_ of plume rose being worked into the pleats in a pinstripe and repeated capriciously in the jadegreen toques in the form of heron feathers of paletinted coral.	9.92542231918357
On leaving the church of Saint Fiacre _in Horto_ after the papal blessing the happy pair were subjected to a playful crossfire of hazelnuts, beechmast, bayleaves, catkins of willow, ivytod, hollyberries, mistletoe sprigs and quicken shoots.	4.493907130072392

—Well, says J.	4.674600629662146

—Tell that to a fool, says the citizen.	13.382446676089799
There’s a bloody sight more pox than pax about that boyo.	8.65004160826812
Edward Guelph-Wettin! —And what do you think, says Joe, of the holy boys, the priests and bishops of Ireland doing up his room in Maynooth in His Satanic Majesty’s racing colours and sticking up pictures of all the horses his jockeys rode.	11.287683990504952
The earl of Dublin, no less.	21.427146865835535
—They ought to have stuck up all the women he rode himself, says little Alf.	16.0010361141986
And says J.	8.305111363869095
J.: —Considerations of space influenced their lordships’ decision.	15.095683474289102
—Will you try another, citizen?	14.315106413112758
—Yes, sir, says he.	4.966638982242802
I will.	14.145629011262553
—You?	53.275171867240395
May your shadow never grow less.	6.16599936056265
—Repeat that dose, says Joe.	3.7595741054536775
Bloom was talking and talking with John Wyse and he quite excited with his dunducketymudcoloured mug on him and his old plumeyes rolling about.	13.10675011499454
—Persecution, says he, all the history of the world is full of it.	10.00133460264643
Perpetuating national hatred among nations.	7.082569710069092
—But do you know what a nation means?	34.25582191360421
—Yes, says Bloom.	5.263571098317217
—A nation?	38.56052964580414
says Bloom.	4.450426075677159
A nation is the same people living in the same place.	16.59838592026924
—By God, then, says Ned, laughing, if that’s so I’m a nation for I’m living in the same place for the past five years.	20.58253301628598
So of course everyone had the laugh at Bloom and says he, trying to muck out of it: —Or also living in different places.	15.120449648234638
—That covers my case, says Joe.	8.397627104070038
—What is your nation if I may ask?	16.705032945561364
I was born here.	13.360040880192098
Ireland.	13.667053076115803
The citizen said nothing only cleared the spit out of his gullet and, gob, he spat a Red bank oyster out of him right in the corner.	12.278591866185902
—After you with the push, Joe, says he, taking out his handkerchief to swab himself dry.	9.909501731155812
—Here you are, citizen, says Joe.	5.825025285441764
Take that in your right hand and repeat after me the following words.	15.906674627466437
The muchtreasured and intricately embroidered ancient Irish facecloth attributed to Solomon of Droma and Manus Tomaltach og MacDonogh, authors of the Book of Ballymote, was then carefully produced and called forth prolonged admiration.	6.051621772421809
No need to dwell on the legendary beauty of the cornerpieces, the acme of art, wherein one can distinctly discern each of the four evangelists in turn presenting to each of the four masters his evangelical symbol, a bogoak sceptre, a North American puma (a far nobler king of beasts than the British article, be it said in passing), a Kerry calf and a golden eagle from Carrantuohill.	12.865409860768466
The scenes depicted on the emunctory field, showing our ancient duns and raths and cromlechs and grianauns and seats of learning and maledictive stones, are as wonderfully beautiful and the pigments as delicate as when the Sligo illuminators gave free rein to their artistic fantasy long long ago in the time of the Barmecides.	8.049179931664407
Glendalough, the lovely lakes of Killarney, the ruins of Clonmacnois, Cong Abbey, Glen Inagh and the Twelve Pins, Ireland’s Eye, the Green Hills of Tallaght, Croagh Patrick, the brewery of Messrs Arthur Guinness, Son and Company (Limited), Lough Neagh’s banks, the vale of Ovoca, Isolde’s tower, the Mapas obelisk, Sir Patrick Dun’s hospital, Cape Clear, the glen of Aherlow, Lynch’s castle, the Scotch house, Rathdown Union Workhouse at Loughlinstown, Tullamore jail, Castleconnel rapids, Kilballymacshonakill, the cross at Monasterboice, Jury’s Hotel, S.	9.628239865833413
Patrick’s Purgatory, the Salmon Leap, Maynooth college refectory, Curley’s hole, the three birthplaces of the first duke of Wellington, the rock of Cashel, the bog of Allen, the Henry Street Warehouse, Fingal’s Cave—all these moving scenes are still there for us today rendered more beautiful still by the waters of sorrow which have passed over them and by the rich incrustations of time.	13.613303003341853
—Show us over the drink, says I.	15.94048369006223
Which is which?	12.872306092276881
—That’s mine, says Joe, as the devil said to the dead policeman.	23.969883247935304
—And I belong to a race too, says Bloom, that is hated and persecuted.	22.803397684718956
Also now.	5.230698116280242
This very instant.	10.333135095970073
Gob, he near burnt his fingers with the butt of his old cigar.	24.023047693185237
—Robbed, says he.	4.565183974537502
Plundered.	32.13581597679176
Insulted.	32.13581597679176
Persecuted.	32.13581597679176
Taking what belongs to us by right.	9.114528479170154
At this very moment, says he, putting up his fist, sold by auction in Morocco like slaves or cattle.	11.094268664578868
—Are you talking about the new Jerusalem?	30.060196038060393
—I’m talking about injustice, says Bloom.	7.423435255278216
—Right, says John Wyse.	7.723526302071231
Stand up to it then with force like men.	15.439854299588818
Mark for a softnosed bullet.	17.999420268805498
Old lardyface standing up to the business end of a gun.	17.846151286092766
Gob, he’d adorn a sweepingbrush, so he would, if he only had a nurse’s apron on him.	11.541630661275173
And then he collapses all of a sudden, twisting around all the opposite, as limp as a wet rag.	18.16716709302787
—But it’s no use, says he.	13.827040127294412
Force, hatred, history, all that.	7.1397862621381565
That’s not life for men and women, insult and hatred.	13.280009667101183
And everybody knows that it’s the very opposite of that that is really life.	17.89477077331972
—Love, says Bloom.	8.6646559224618
I mean the opposite of hatred.	22.304692245730703
I must go now, says he to John Wyse.	19.05942908502449
If he comes just say I’ll be back in a second.	19.225042328843926
Just a moment.	8.115862258608747
Who’s hindering you?	13.897241907851816
And off he pops like greased lightning.	6.439517246972131

Universal love.	8.166345857871713

Love, moya! He’s a nice pattern of a Romeo and Juliet.	14.183834946244334

And he ups with his pint to wet his whistle.	14.346328271340974
What about sanctimonious Cromwell and his ironsides that put the women and children of Drogheda to the sword with the bible text _God is love_ pasted round the mouth of his cannon?	14.191041415432412
The bible! Did you read that skit in the _United Irishman_ today about that Zulu chief that’s visiting England?	10.900296803119717
—What’s that?	9.356975705049678
So the citizen takes up one of his paraphernalia papers and he starts reading out: —A delegation of the chief cotton magnates of Manchester was presented yesterday to His Majesty the Alaki of Abeakuta by Gold Stick in Waiting, Lord Walkup of Walkup on Eggs, to tender to His Majesty the heartfelt thanks of British traders for the facilities afforded them in his dominions.	8.400809145585598
The delegation partook of luncheon at the conclusion of which the dusky potentate, in the course of a happy speech, freely translated by the British chaplain, the reverend Ananias Praisegod Barebones, tendered his best thanks to Massa Walkup and emphasised the cordial relations existing between Abeakuta and the British empire, stating that he treasured as one of his dearest possessions an illuminated bible, the volume of the word of God and the secret of England’s greatness, graciously presented to him by the white chief woman, the great squaw Victoria, with a personal dedication from the august hand of the Royal Donor.	11.30630012852096
The Alaki then drank a lovingcup of firstshot usquebaugh to the toast _Black and White_ from the skull of his immediate predecessor in the dynasty Kakachakachak, surnamed Forty Warts, after which he visited the chief factory of Cottonopolis and signed his mark in the visitors’ book, subsequently executing a charming old Abeakutic wardance, in the course of which he swallowed several knives and forks, amid hilarious applause from the girl hands.	8.560232379798743
—Widow woman, says Ned.	9.658785309610906
I wouldn’t doubt her.	7.0633165503940605
Wonder did he put that bible to the same use as I would.	35.7065020275245
—Same only more so, says Lenehan.	6.597992582405012

Bet you what you like he has a hundred shillings to five on.	12.518932121709412
He’s the only man in Dublin has it.	9.199098511609693
A dark horse.	15.531950657884844

—There you are, says Terry.	15.99541193361409
Goodbye Ireland I’m going to Gort.	9.924203248506629
So I just went round the back of the yard to pumpship and begob (hundred shillings to five) while I was letting off my _(Throwaway_ twenty to) letting off my load gob says I to myself I knew he was uneasy in his (two pints off of Joe and one in Slattery’s off) in his mind to get off the mark to (hundred shillings is five quid) and when they were in the (dark horse) pisser Burke was telling me card party and letting on the child was sick (gob, must have done about a gallon) flabbyarse of a wife speaking down the tube _she’s better_ or _she’s_ (ow!) all a plan so he could vamoose with the pool if he won or (Jesus, full up I was) trading without a licence (ow!) Ireland my nation says he (hoik! phthook!) never be up to those bloody (there’s the last of it) Jerusalem (ah!) cuckoos.	13.896901939434374
So anyhow when I got back they were at it dingdong, John Wyse saying it was Bloom gave the ideas for Sinn Fein to Griffith to put in his paper all kinds of jerrymandering, packed juries and swindling the taxes off of the government and appointing consuls all over the world to walk about selling Irish industries.	11.840956272228045
Robbing Peter to pay Paul.	11.003389289432054
Gob, that puts the bloody kybosh on it if old sloppy eyes is mucking up the show.	13.267106653505039
Give us a bloody chance.	19.0141472388984
God save Ireland from the likes of that bloody mouseabout.	24.688896710231454
Mr Bloom with his argol bargol.	22.23199198157857
And his old fellow before him perpetrating frauds, old Methusalem Bloom, the robbing bagman, that poisoned himself with the prussic acid after he swamping the country with his baubles and his penny diamonds.	16.250900324041723
Distance no object.	12.872306092276881
No security.	16.58211792698403
Gob, he’s like Lanty MacHale’s goat that’d go a piece of the road with every one.	17.356089220191812
—Well, it’s a fact, says John Wyse.	8.486616455148013
And there’s the man now that’ll tell you all about it, Martin Cunningham.	18.779146623576832
Sure enough the castle car drove up with Martin on it and Jack Power with him and a fellow named Crofter or Crofton, pensioner out of the collector general’s, an orangeman Blackburn does have on the registration and he drawing his pay or Crawford gallivanting around the country at the king’s expense.	15.381561551661328
Our travellers reached the rustic hostelry and alighted from their palfreys.	7.408734375991648
—Ho, varlet! cried he, who by his mien seemed the leader of the party.	16.070390995620905
Mine host came forth at the summons, girding him with his tabard.	18.27040897514224
—Give you good den, my masters, said he with an obsequious bow.	17.610410000170297
Look to our steeds.	20.04451395463994
And for ourselves give us of your best for ifaith we need it.	5.754472793555277
—Lackaday, good masters, said the host, my poor house has but a bare larder.	14.635140146010462
I know not what to offer your lordships.	14.130464518118183
—How now, fellow?	22.116181802258176
An instantaneous change overspread the landlord’s visage.	10.839686148685285
—Cry you mercy, gentlemen, he said humbly.	11.550301961083264
An you be the king’s messengers (God shield His Majesty!) you shall not want for aught.	14.32609254159975
The king’s friends (God bless His Majesty!) shall not go afasting in my house I warrant me.	10.101622815354919
—Then about! cried the traveller who had not spoken, a lusty trencherman by his aspect.	15.232044296979536
Hast aught to give us?	15.028602836900554
Mine host bowed again as he made answer: —What say you, good masters, to a squab pigeon pasty, some collops of venison, a saddle of veal, widgeon with crisp hog’s bacon, a boar’s head with pistachios, a bason of jolly custard, a medlar tansy and a flagon of old Rhenish?	14.125376627232981
—Gadzooks! cried the last speaker.	14.405010448017913
That likes me well.	7.144484492770881
A poor house and a bare larder, quotha! ’Tis a merry rogue.	13.55299855300525

The observatory of Dunsink registered in all eleven shocks, all of the fifth grade of Mercalli’s scale, and there is no record extant of a similar seismic disturbance in our island since the earthquake of 1534, the year of the rebellion of Silken Thomas.	12.843414871516623
The epicentre appears to have been that part of the metropolis which constitutes the Inn’s Quay ward and parish of Saint Michan covering a surface of fortyone acres, two roods and one square pole or perch.	8.326336260023576
All the lordly residences in the vicinity of the palace of justice were demolished and that noble edifice itself, in which at the time of the catastrophe important legal debates were in progress, is literally a mass of ruins beneath which it is to be feared all the occupants have been buried alive.	11.89501332401674
From the reports of eyewitnesses it transpires that the seismic waves were accompanied by a violent atmospheric perturbation of cyclonic character.	5.847835800184608
An article of headgear since ascertained to belong to the much respected clerk of the crown and peace Mr George Fottrell and a silk umbrella with gold handle with the engraved initials, crest, coat of arms and house number of the erudite and worshipful chairman of quarter sessions sir Frederick Falkiner, recorder of Dublin, have been discovered by search parties in remote parts of the island respectively, the former on the third basaltic ridge of the giant’s causeway, the latter embedded to the extent of one foot three inches in the sandy beach of Holeopen bay near the old head of Kinsale.	11.947274011479278

Messages of condolence and sympathy are being hourly received from all parts of the different continents and the sovereign pontiff has been graciously pleased to decree that a special _missa pro defunctis_ shall be celebrated simultaneously by the ordinaries of each and every cathedral church of all the episcopal dioceses subject to the spiritual authority of the Holy See in suffrage of the souls of those faithful departed who have been so unexpectedly called away from our midst.	10.347758233279194

[ 13 ] The summer evening had begun to fold the world in its mysterious embrace.	8.95041035753519
Far away in the west the sun was setting and the last glow of all too fleeting day lingered lovingly on sea and strand, on the proud promontory of dear old Howth guarding as ever the waters of the bay, on the weedgrown rocks along Sandymount shore and, last but not least, on the quiet church whence there streamed forth at times upon the stillness the voice of prayer to her who is in her pure radiance a beacon ever to the stormtossed heart of man, Mary, star of the sea.	12.334276766108944
